1.content:
I slashed, only to strike the empty air where that … monster had once been. Or maybe it was a demon? Hard to tell. It raised it’s left hand and targeted me, which was simply my cue to dodge. That scorching beam of red shot out of it’s fingertips, exploding into the far wall and melting a small section of stones together. No charcoal was left behind, nothing burst into flames, the marks on the wall weren’t even that noticeable. Hard to believe assassination could be so much simpler when a dark wizard is hired for the job.

He didn’t seem to care that his shot missed, the dark cloaked figure slowly made it’s way towards the king’s bedchamber. He had a few more hallways to go through and all of them were lined with more guards, the majority more skilled and better armed than myself. Heck, I couldn’t even afford an enchanted blade like half of my squad wielded. But in light of what I could see first hand I didn’t think any of it would matter. I readied my blade, charged the spell caster from behind, and made my best attempt to cheer under the suffocating silence, but nothing seemed to matter. There was no scream in pain, none of his continuous spells relented, he didn’t even slow down.

At this point, you might be wondering why I was fighting alone. Why hadn’t I sounded any alarm, or called for the aid of the entire castle staff? The simple answer is, that I did. It’s protocol, you don’t get to play the hero if you want to succeed. But none of them made a sound. The clattering of steel as my sword swiped across his dagger was absent, the warning claxon made not a sound as I smashed metal onto metal. I screamed at the air, shouting to my companions, to no effect. Not even the thundering explosions of the many spells I had to dodge made their usual clatter.

All the more reason to hate magic.

Next you might be wondering just what I look like. To be honest? I don’t actually remember. Mirrors are hard to come by when you spend most of your time training and the rest standing guard, and this was the last night I would ever have the power of a human body. The monster? This frustrating spell caster wasn’t much to look at either, but I least I remember what I could see. Black. That’s about it, black in a dark room on a moonless night. There weren’t any details to his face, just a blob of fog that seemed to slide past his lips and swirl around his head. I couldn’t see any hair past the pitch black hood over his skull, and the black robes he wore covered every part of his form save the hands. And they looked black too … not black as the extremely tan foreigners from the sun baked regions south of the kingdom, black as in pitch-black, blending perfectly with the night sky.

That was probably magic too.

Annoyed that stabbing through his lungs had no noticeable effect, I gripped the hilt of my blade steadily and twisted, gouging through what I could only hope was flesh and bone, before dazzling light exploded in my eyes and the floor fell out from under me. I was on my knees, my hands cupping my swollen eyes, tears of pain and frustration mixing with charred flesh and made all the more terrible by my inability to scream. But I wasn’t about to give up, ha! Guess I was just too stubborn to let a simple face melting slow me down. I looked across the room to see the black garbed wizard walk calmly through the halls with my sword jutting out between his shoulder blades.

I smiled when I saw my captain, fallowed closely by four other well armed and well armored knights, charge the beast head on. I guess they must have seen the spell casting, or noticed my battle by now. One heavily enchanted blade raised high and swung down, surely with enough force to cleave a man in two. But the monster blurred and dodged with incredible speed, zipping around and through the other guards as if they were children. Another swing, missed entirely. I saw Charles shouting mutely as he stabbed forward, but his blade only seemed to catch clothing … before it ran through the man next to him.

It’s weird, utterly weird, to hear silence when you know a man in screaming at the top of his lungs. If a healer got here in time that wound would be nothing, but otherwise … my fellow guard would not even be allowed the luxury of a dieing breath, any last words he make would fall on deaf ears.

I hate magic.

What was even more odd, the monster never moved that fast when I was fighting him. Why not? Undeterred by such constant failure against this foe, I rushed forward with my bare hands, I would give my life to stop any attack against the king. The monster turned at the last second, raised a glowing hand aimed towards my chest, just before my world exploded into pain. I felt I was stretched and squeezed, torn from all sides with daggers slicing through my skin and nose from under my flesh. I passed out.

Even though it didn’t kill me, I had indeed given my life for the king. As I soon found out waking up in a …
1.title: Last Day

It was a horse and carrage.
11.content:
Forest. I thought it was a forest at least, that’s what it usually means when there are lots and lots of trees all over the place. I felt odd at first, because they seemed much bigger than trees were supposed to be. Distorted or something. But stupid me, I had the silliest idea that was only because I was laying on my back, that the trees would look normal once I sat up. Nope. I twitched my whiskers as I pondered the matter. The only place in the world with trees that big was Stranothlas, in the elven territories. If one were to include other worlds, this could have been Felarya.

I shuddered at that thought, my tail curled around my fuzz covered chest in fear. The portals to that ghastly place were long sense closed off by a legendary band of heroes. But any mage with teleportation magics and enough power could conceivably send people there. As a punishment, or as a combat tactic it was even practical. What could be a more frightening spell than sending someone to the second most dangerous place imaginable? Well, Ok there were probably worse spells. I thought I was probably lucky I wasn’t transformed into a piece of woman’s undergarments, or a flower, or a toadstool.

And whatever all I had to face, I was at least still alive? Right? This place didn’t resemble heaven in the slightest, and none of the rings of hell were this pleasant. Unless someone happened to do some remodeling since the last person escaped to tell everyone else what it was like. I could move my arms, I could stand up just fine. My feet felt awkward and my legs were heavy, but I could deal with such minor problems. I was filled with both optimism and curiosity when my slow witted mind finally noticed I was staring at a patch of grass taller than I was. Either it wasn’t just the trees that were so huge, or … heh, I forgot what I was thinking there.

Too busy noticing I had a tail, a long and stringy one. Too confused to be horrified (not to say the fear wasn’t there) I stepped back to try to look at everything. I saw my nose, a triangular shaped pink thing at the end of my face. I saw my whiskers, long stringy, bouncy little hairs that jutted out the side of my upper jaw. I held shaky, panicky arms up over my head to feel the hair … I wasn’t bald, far from it, but too busy poking and prodding my newfound ears to worry about fuzziness.

Those things were huge! Huge I tell you! They felt more like sheets of paper than ears, frankly, they were just so thin and flat. And soft. And warm, very warm. By now my breath was rapid, my chest and arms were rigid, stiff … I had faced a good many terrifying things in my day, I wasn’t about to let my own body scare the wits out of me. Even if it wasn’t quite mine. There wasn’t a mirror laying around, story of my life, but the sun was at just the right angle for me to get a look at my shadow. I could see the basic shape, my silhouette portrayed against the ground.

“I will not scream at the sight of my shadow” I told myself as I examined what had been done. My body, instead of whatever it used to look like, now sported wide hips with short hind legs. A long stringy tail curling around and waving through the air behind me. Flexible ears at the top of my head, a pointed, angular face as opposed the flat face I should have had. My shoulders were thin, but that matched my neck. My arms were skinny, but my paws were about as large as my normal hands would be. Comparatively.

“I will not scream at the sight of my shadow” I had to remind myself, I simply was not going to scream. I was trained too well for that. I’ve taken broken bones in stride, surely this little spell wasn’t going to mess with me. I was a mouse.

I tiny one, unless everything around me was just disproportionately huge. And … naked. Apparently. I didn’t notice that part for a while thanks to all this fur, but then unless I could find a teeny tiny merchant it wasn’t going to matter. Er, even if I could it still wasn’t going to matter. Did I have any gold on me? Nope. No pockets, no bags, no place to hold any coin, so I certainly didn’t have any. That wasn’t much different from my usual state of affairs.

What was different was the fact I had neither armor nor sword. Even if mine were cheap, mass produced, and utterly laughable compared to the more successful fighters and bounty hunters, I never went anywhere without one. Man, it would be hard to try and carry a sword fifty times bigger than I was …

“But can I still speak?” I asked aloud, effectively answering my own question. I didn’t think my voice sounded squeaky or mouse-like, rather normal actually. But that could just be a part of the spell, a perception filter or some mind trick that lets me understand other mice, at the cost of rendering me unintelligible to humans. But even if that were the case, it would still be better having to speak with actual squeaks and chatters. And if I could speak clear and understandable Uema …

“Ok, so first things first, when I meet anyone I will ask for directions.” I told myself. Mostly just to hear my own voice and take comfort. I sounded like myself. “If I am the proper size for a mouse, then I can assume these trees are their normal height. That’s good, I guess … but I still want to know what forest this is.”

I took a single step … and fell flat on my face. Chin really.

“Omph!” I curled onto one side, cupped my furless little mouse paws over my nose, and lamented on the very idea of failure to walk. It did not take long for the pain to die down, and upon standing back to my feet I stubbornly re-attempted that step. I discovered stubbornness is not a virtue when I fell forward for the second time, but now I was ready. I braced myself with my arms … front paws … and landed softly on four legs.

Quite suddenly this body felt natural, easy and accommodating rather than strange and alien. Curious, I started walking without bothering to get up. I slinked and scurried through the grass, my tail held up off the ground as it trailed soundlessly behind me. I wasn’t able to see over the grass, and I had no idea where I was going, but I felt like I was making good speed. Walking like this was, in a word, easy. I just didn’t like how much it made me feel like a mouse, crawling on all fours with your face just millimeters off the ground just isn’t … human.

Once I came to a dirt covered clearing, when I could see the sky past an opening in the trees and green grass no longer closed in around me, I stood up. That part was natural. Turns out mice can stand up easily and readily, their front paws really did double as hands when they needed. My tail propped up against the ground, my spine bent into a relaxed slump. But I didn’t want to just stand there, I had to be able to walk on two legs as well.

Could mice even do that? Seems like they should be able to. But as soon as I stepped forward, flailing my arms and tail to keep from falling again, I realized it was much harder than it should be. My legs just weren’t shaped for walking as I normally would. The hips were too wide, the legs were too short and bend all the wrong directions, my feet looked huge compared to the rest of me. Not to mention there was all this fatty, loose skin that just made everything feel awkward.

Sighing to myself, I felt my whiskers widen and my right ear perk up, then swivel around at some sound in the distance. I couldn’t tell what it was, and at the moment I was simply too distracted to care. I had to find a way to walk upright, that was my primary goal for the moment. I could even distinguish myself from a normal mouse if I really got the hang of it. That sound seemed to be getting closer, and I wondered with an idle abandon just what it could be.

I took two steps, making wide and exaggerated movements so that it felt more like wobbling, but I stayed up. My lips curled into a smile, stretching my whiskers at an odd angle in the process.

“There we go, just need practice.” until the sound that had been mildly annoying became a pressing concern. As I turned to the right and a shadow fell over me, I could feel the unrelenting fear of a mouse surround my consciousness. My large, black eyes looked up in awe and horror. It was in that moment I figured out why this ground was clear, it was a road. A dirt road, and I had been standing right in the middle.

With this little fact sinking in, I made out the details of what had snuck up on me … I was determined not to scream, so very determined, despite the terror I felt …

I squeaked.
11.title: Forest

Stay on the road and wait for another traveler.
Slow down, stop worrying, and fallow the road.
111.content:
STOMP!

A horse’s hoof slammed into the ground just inches from my face. I felt my tail go stiff with fear, my whiskers spread out, the fur all across my back stood on end. I was cowardly for but a moment, believing it was the end as dirt was splashed across my chest and legs. But then it lifted up … and up … and up. And the horse stepped over me, stomping noisily and dangerously down that same unpaved road.

I rushed back towards the grass before facing a similar encounter with it’s hind legs, and no I didn’t care about staying upright during my frantic fleeing. Four legs just made rushing to safety that much faster.

STOMP! The tan furred horse just kept walking. I looked up to see it’s black tail flicking the air to deter flies, I could see it’s brown leather saddle, I could see … it’s rider! Now was my chance!

“H-Hey! Heeello up there!” I called out from the thin but tall grass as the pair passed by. They didn’t respond, but it’s not like I should expect him too. Er, him? Yeah that rider looked human. The horse was clearly male, but from my angle that was a detail I would not have preferred to focus on. I crawled … walked? Ran? Yeah, lets go with ran. It’s so hard to tell with this new body.

I ran after them squeaking and hollering, but the constant stomping and clattering of a horse’s four hooves proved too much noise for a mouse to overcome. I started leaping into the air, waving my front paws around, screaming at the top of my lungs, nothing seemed to work. The fact I could barely hear myself over that horse probably had something to do with it.

And by the gods, that horse was fast! Barely even trotting, I was exhausting myself trying to keep up with it while simultaneously attempting to draw attention. Made worse by the fact I was failing at both. Something had to give, so I stayed my breath and silently raced after the two. I’d learned long ago that humans are silent fighters, when it comes to matters of life and death we instinctively avoid speaking. The logic is that one should not waste breath when their life is in danger, so all air, all energy is instead focused on the task at hand.

I wasn’t sure if mice had the same instinct, probably did considering they were almost always quiet, but it was a great relief to my lungs when I stopped shouting. My tiny little mouse feet slapped the road as I sped forward, my head was so low I could feel my whiskers tickling through the loose dirt. But there was no way I could keep up with even a slow horse indefinitely. What if I stopped trying?

I was on a well used road, it’s certainly plausible to wait for the next traveler to come along. Hopefully either someone on foot, or at least paying more attention to the … “wildlife”

Then of course, I could just fallow the road to wherever this man is going. What if it leads to a city? Or some small town surrounded by farmland? If I could find a city it would be easy to figure out where that spell-caster sent me. But then, this traveler was on a horse. So what if his destination was some distance away? If the nearest city was days away by horse, it might take me weeks, or even months to reach it on my own. And that is under the assumption I survive the wildlife. Woods can be dangerous enough at night when your six feet tall wielding a longsword. But two inches tall, sporting a tail, and unarmed?

Wolves alone would be impossible to fight. And as a mouse I’d be at risk for other things like cats … or owls … or … snakes maybe. By the gods, there are a lot of animals that eat mice. Was I really willing to risk a long, arduous journey through unknown territory with such a curse?

My legs started to grow tired, but I could muscle through for a while longer. If I could manage the jump, I might be able to catch a ride with this fellow. Doing so might even draw his attention. But was it worth the effort? Or the risk? If I got stepped on there would be no survival.

I looked up to see the horse flicking it’s tail back and forwarth, then drop down … decisions. Decisions.
111.title: It was a horse and rider.

choices: I made it to the top.
I lost my grip and fell.
The horse flicked it's tail, sending me flying.
1111.content:
Run! I needed to speed up if I wanted to make the jump. This was more than just keeping up, I had to run much faster than the horse’s slow trot so as to overtake it. Thank whatever god may be listening that it was close enough, and slow enough, for me to accomplish this with a short burst. After I got on and started to ride would be much less tiresome than all this running.

My lungs started to burn once more, I was running with such ferocity I could hear the pitter-patter of my feet against the ground even over that horrid clomping noise of the stallion. I could even hear the wind in my ears and feel it across my face.

Run … LEAP! I coiled my hind legs at the last possible second, kicked the ground with intense force, and held my arms high above my head and in front of my chest as I sailed through the air at two feet off the ground. I’ll say one thing for this new mouse body, it could jump! Inches away from grabbing those long, stringy hairs of the horse’s tail, it swung to the side and flew high above my head. My arms grabbed nothing, I panicked.

Twisting around in midair, I tried to grab it a second time around, but such miniscule arms could not possibly close that distance. I fell, landed hard on my back, and curled up in both pain and preparation. The momentum was enough to carry me forward after I hit dirt, so rolling was preferable to flailing.

SMASH! The horse hadn’t even slowed down, the back of it’s hoof swung backward ever so slightly as it was walking. The hard hoof seemed to come out of nowhere, pain simply exploded into the back of my skull, fallowed closely by my nose, my chest, my spine, and my tail as I ricocheted off. The whiplash from switching directions so quickly and smashing into the ground unprepared wasn’t fun either.

I took a leisurely two seconds to cradle my aching skull. Took another lengthy second to make sure everything was still attached and no broken bones required a splint. Three full seconds, much too long in my opinion, to find the still trotting horse and orient in on it, then finally, finally ran after it to make another leap.

This time running was a heck of a lot harder, my legs seemed about ready to give way at any moment. It was hard to focus, hard to keep my eyes open, with such an annoying headache. My spine wasn’t handling the strain of all the flexing, bending, and bouncing that goes on in a mouse’s run as well as it had before. My body was constantly screaming at me to slow down, or stop. It said to pay attention to those wounds and make absolutely sure this sort of damage doesn’t repeat itself.

I was never very good at listening to things like that.

I neared the tail again, watched it twitch up high out of my reach to swat a fly, then fall back down … swinging. Dangling. I leapt! My paws outstret- … paws? No, hands! Think of them as hands moron. With my hands outstretched I gripped hair, I felt my full weight slump down as my arms now took the full force of that evil, evil gravity. My momentum carried me forward, the tail yielded, and it was like swinging on a vine.

I saw legs thicker than trees rushing past on either side of me, I saw the fat, round belly over my head, that light tan colored fur above and around me. Then the tail swung backwards, the warmth of such a large body was noticeably absent. Time seemed to slow as there was no longer constant movement, I saw the mildly unpleasant view of … yeah … this horse didn’t have any more cloths than I did. Not nearly as disgusting when your human sized than it is when your mouse sized. Any foul smelling orifice I can fit inside isn’t something I want to think about.

And then it was past. The tail had reached the end of it’s arch and started to swing back down between the two legs. Assured in the fact I had a firm grip, and a decent feel for the swinging tail, I began to climb. It was like rope climbing, but there was a lot more ropes than usual. And all of them were much thinner and stronger than any rope I’ve ever encountered.

My bruises felt as if now was the time to remind me of their existence ...

and …
1111.title: Rush forward and grab the tail.

11111.content:
I had to make it to the top, swinging back and forwarth on this “ride” was faster than running, but I knew I’d tire eventually. And there was always that nagging little worry, what if another fly came by and the horse had to flick it’s tail? I started to climb.

One arm gripped with all the strength I could muster and tightened to lift me higher, while the other arm spread out as far above my head as it could reach. Then that hand secured a nice firm grip, while the other hand let go and reached up. I was making progress. But after five times, roughly a quarter of the way up, they started to buckle under the strain.

My head still wasn’t letting me forget the blunt force trauma I took, and my spine seemed to be competing with the rest of my body to see what could hurt the most. But I couldn’t rest now, so I wasn’t going to. Gritting my teeth, I repeated the process again. And again. And again.

“Ergn!” I grunted, a little over halfway up the strain was unbearable. The pain spread from my arms to my fingertips, my accent slowed as it became harder and harder to find that next grip. At least the tail wasn’t swinging anymore. I was too far up and too secure to sway back and forwarth. My arms started to shake, I was loosing my grip.

“NO!” I shouted with determination filling my eyes. My whiskers grew stiff, but I held them tight against my muzzle so they wouldn’t get in the way. No amount of pain was going to slow me down, so long as I had arms I was darn well going to use them.

I stretched, reached, gripped, and was rewarded with another inch towards my goal. My legs dangling bellow me touched lightly against the tough, yielding flesh of the equine’s rump. The flesh twitched, and that was the moment I realized my mistake. The tail twitched immediately after.

Woosh! The world rocketed to one side, SLAM!

I felt my shoulder crash into the horse’s side. Then I felt the tail swinging back. I never let go, certainly wasn’t that stupid, but by the gods this pain on top of my fast growing exhaustion was horrible! My breathing instantly went fast and shallow, my tail waved around franticly as if it were trying to grip something. Out of reflex I could feel my feet grip the horse’s tail just as tightly as my hands.

Wait … my feet? On a moment of reflection I could grip almost as well with my feet as I could with my hands. Oh, yeah. As a mouse there wasn’t a whole lot of distinction between the two. Using both feet, I suddenly had three braces and four firm grips while moving and climbing. This was much, much easier.

Then I slipped. Well, my left foot did. They could grip better than human feet (a lot better) but they weren’t quite a match for my front paws. Front hands. Hands! Goddammit, think of them as hands!

Another two inches up the tail. Another three inches. I was almost there, much to the relief of every aching joint and worn out muscle I had. I detected an utterly horrible smell as I passed directly between the horse’s butt cheeks, but ignored it as best I could while climbing over. I could have held my breath, but momentary displeasure was well worth the price of a steady air supply.

And then I was over. Sitting on the very back of a horse as it trotted lazily through a serene patch of woods. I stared up at the brown, leather saddle of the rider. I saw the strange, patchwork clothing of his pants and shirt, covered by a well worn jacket and a large straw hat. I could not tell what style of clothing this was, but his skin was white and sun baked. A farmer perhaps? Or just a farmhand with some experience.

The entire ride jerked and bounced uncontrollably. I gripped the much smaller hairs up here for balance, but as I scurried over towards the saddle I discovered I had no need to find a firm grip. On four legs, this mouse body had wonderful balance. I could easily compensate for the constant motion.

Curling up underneath the back, squeezing myself in a small crack between the horse’s back and the saddle, I finally began to relax and enjoy the landscape.
11111.title: I made it to the top.

choices: I woke up in a small, rural town.
I woke up in a stable, surrounded by horses.
111111.content:
As a mouse, hiding inside this slim little crack made me feel safe and secure. Warmth and fuzz surrounded me, there was constant, unrelenting movement bellow my feet. The smell wasn’t anything to relish over, too much sweat and dirt and … horse. Sweaty horse. But having spent so much time around sweaty, smelly humans swinging slabs of metal at each other, I felt I could handle worse.

I yawned, I stretched my arms and my back, I let my tail curl up around my feet. I allowed all my aches and pains to wash over me, as I closed my eyes and rested. My whiskers twitched, my little pink mouse nose fallowing the example. I even went so far as to relax my head, laying down completely.

This was a good place to sleep. A very good place.

I propped one eye open to survey the landscape, taking note of those tall mountains in the distance, the type of trees surrounding this area, how far down the road I could see with no sign of a building or farmland. It wasn’t very far, much to my disappointment. Too many trees, too many turns, even if most were minor.

I closed my eye once more and thought … just thought. Yesterday morning I woke up, got dressed, ate breakfast, and reported for guard duty. It was a simple job where, for the most part, you just stand there and stay vigilant. If you weren’t a very good guard it could quickly turn boring, but the very moment that changed you suddenly wished you had remained alert.

I was trained to fight against mystical beasts, massive dragons, armed and armored soldiers from neighboring lands. Before I ever went anywhere near the castle I had gained experience guarding small provinces from roaming thieves, and lived long enough to note the very distinct difference in fighting style they employed.

I had been trained to recognize magic, to avoid offensive spells, and above all, to never … ever … piss off a powerful wizard if I had some other option. Learning that lesson taught me to hate magic, and I don’t think that’s ever left me.

But now? Now I wake up, in the middle of the day, naked, without a weapon, and in a body no longer my own. I was some distance from home, no matter where I happened to be. The castle guard and king Lostral probably thought I was dead. For all I knew, the king himself could be turned into a mouse! The same fate could have befallen the entire guard.

Or, you know … they could all be dead. I am not sure which I would prefer, the king, and all of my friends being degraded in such a manner? Left to wonder the castle walls and fall prey to much more terrifying creatures, and much worse fates than a spell. Or if they were all killed outright, quickly and silently.

Hmm, no … I would rather they live. No matter how horrible life may be at times, it is always better than not having one. That’s the attitude I needed to have, and that’s the attitude I held onto as my mind drifted into slumber. Fallowed very closely by …

“God I hate magic”

And I meant every word.
111111.title: I fell asleep.

choices: I asked the rider to stop.
1111111.content:
I awoke to the smell of apple pie, the clop-clopping of a horse on crude pavement, and the empty gurgling of my own stomach begging for food. I yawned. I stretched. I opened my eyes in wonder at just how many humans there were, and how many houses seemed to spring out of nowhere. I was still hidden tightly under that crevice between the horse and the saddle, padded from all sides.

The pain in my head and shoulders were gone, but the base of my spine still seemed sore. Oh well. Turning my head from left to right, I scanned what all I could see from behind the horse’s rump. A blue sky, stringy clouds, mountains that seemed to fade into the distance. Crude but well maintained wooded houses decorated in a simple tan paint that chipped off in several areas to reveal the aged wood underneath. The buildings were dry instead of damp, considering how much wood there was that meant this was midlands. I wasn’t anywhere near the water, and rain or fog weren’t persistent.

It was some time between spring and summer, so I could count on good weather overall around here. The streets looked clean, none of the villagers seemed to be starving or suffering. I could not see any shops, nor a castle, nor any distinguishing feature, but that might have simply been my angle. I yawned for the second time, then crawled out just enough to look around some more.

No trees anywhere nearby, but as I could not see over any of the buildings that was to be expected. My whiskers tasted the air as I took in the scent of … of …

“Gurgle! Earch!” My stomach quickly reminded me that I hadn’t eaten in over a day, depending on how long I had been out between the spell, the teleportation, and falling asleep. I could smell pie in the air, I could smell soups and pastas, I could smell a meaty, brothy stew somewhere in the area. Was everyone eating dinner right now? Or was there some sort of celebration going on?

Either way, if I could find some leftovers, some fresh scraps laying around, then this would be an incredible stroke of luck. I didn’t have any cash so paying for a meal was out of the question. Stealing one? No. Just … just no. No matter what my form I refused to even consider degrading myself like that. The begger and the poor street urchin living off of scraps and refuse had a hundred times more honor than the wealthiest thief in the most luxurious house.

But by the gods, that food smelled delicious. I walked over to the edge of the horse’s rump, looked down over the edge as best I could, then balked at the prospect of getting down. I could try jumping? No … dumb idea. Climbing down the tail again, and simply leaping off when I was close enough to the ground was an option. Or, wait … considering how much closer I was to the rider, I could just get his attention and ask him to stop so I could get off.

That would not seem like an unreasonable demand coming from a mouse, right? I just had to make sure I was polite enough.

Decisions … decisions.
1111111.title: I woke up in a small, rural town.

choices: By trying to shake me off.
11111111.content:
I looked across the large saddle, reached my paws up to grip the nearest end, then hoisted myself over. The horse was still moving, the platform I had to work with was moving slowly, predictably, and constantly … and by the gods, could this mouse body handle it. The level of balance I had was just incredible, on four legs I was as stable here as if I had been on solid ground.

I took a moment to look around from this new vantage point, though the buttocks and back of the yet unknown rider. I sighed to myself, stretched my tail, then felt the instinctive desire to wash up before speaking to anyone. How did mice wash? No. No time to figure it out now.

“H-hello good sir! May you be so kind as to stop the horse?” I called out in a clear, polite voice. It wasn’t much of a demand, and it didn’t derive any reaction out of the man. “I would very much like to depart.” I added as a final measure, hoping he would not dismiss me as some random voice off the nearby streets.

Nothing. He didn’t even notice me. What if I could only speak in squeaks, and no matter how loud or clear I sounded to myself I sounded like a mouse to everyone else? If that was the case there would be nothing I could do, but … what if he simply didn’t hear me? Mice aren’t known for being very loud, it makes sense a mouse’s shouting would not go very far. I sighed, climbed forward ever so carefully, then gripped the man’s jacket.

If I was talking in squeaks this whole ordeal was an effort in futility. But if I just wasn’t loud enough then I could solve the problem by climbing up to his ear. Even if he doesn’t hear me, I am pretty darned sure he’d feel me and wonder how in the world a mouse managed to get way up there. I started to climb, very reminiscent of my accent up the horse’s tail.

The leather was stiff, I found that my fingered struggled to get a grip against the smooth, unyielding surface. But there were seams along the side, and along the man’s extended elbow that I could grip. This was one moment where it really sunk in just how small my fingers were. It was an uneventful climb up towards the armpit, easy clambering over the man’s shoulder, and just astounding when I saw the world from way up high.

Er …

Way up … normal. On top of a horse wasn’t very high compared to a castle roof, but from my current size this was just incredible. Looking away from the spectacle I thought about what I could say, what should I say. Well, no matter what manages to come out of my mouth, the reaction any random villager would give upon having a mouse talk to them … or squeak at them … is surprise. And if the man jumps around, or flails, or tries to shake me off, I am sure even my newfound balancing skills would be hard pressed.

I reached out, slowly, and ever so quietly, to grab the shaggy blond hair for a nice firm grip. I leaned close, my head near the man’s ear, and spoke as clearly as I could.

“Excuse me good sir, would you be so kind as to help me down?” to which he responded …
11111111.title: I asked the rider to stop.

111111111.content:
The man turned sharply, as if deeply startled by my presence. But upon seeing my grey fur, my thin, whispy little whiskers, my long stringy tail, and the fact I was small enough to sit on his shoulder … he was too stunned to form a proper reaction of any sort.

“Sir?” I repeated calmly. My hands … paws … no wait, hands! Hands! My hands still gripped a section of his hair just in case, but as his head turned the strand was pulled taunt. “I do not mean to intrude, but could very much use your assistance.”

“Th- … th-th … Y-y-you’re a …” the man stammered. Barely able to forge a sentence without butchering it with his shaky nerves. At least he could understand me. I felt the need to reassure him.

“I deeply apologize for this, but I am not having a most favorable day myself. Simply slow your horse so that I may depart and I will trouble you no longer.”

“M-m- … m-mouse … y-you’re a …” he was getting better.

“Indeed I am, though not of my own choosing. I would have much rather been a dragon, or an amorak, or perhaps an ogre. But I do apologize for my frightening appearance.” not one word of that statement was a lie. If I were an ogre I’d at least draw attention, and be able to fight. If I were a dragon, disregarding the awesome factor completely, I would have had wings to make finding my way and my king so much easier. And as a mouse I must have been frightening. The sight of my face alone had left this man speechless.

“Y-yeah. Alright, I’ll bite. Yeah. There’s some magic going on here.”

“The answer to half of every impossible question. The other half can be answered with ‘A wizard did it’ … by the gods I hate magic.” I responded.

“Yes. Erm, yes of course.” he seemed nervous all of a sudden. His eyes never left me as he stopped his horse in the middle of the road. I could see sweat forming up in little beads across his eyebrow. That was curious, but the man cupped his hands around me … paused as if afraid of retaliation … then hopped off his saddle and placed me on the nearby sidewalk in haste.

His arms shakily withdrew, he paused but a moment to smile nervously towards a passing villager, then leapt onto the saddle. At his insistent direction, that horse was racing down the street long before the shaken traveler had finished seating himself. He wasn’t frightened enough to flick me away on first sighting … or maybe he was too afraid to do anything but fallow orders. Why?

Well I’ve had some experience with magic and magic users in my time. This most recent curse should be a testament to how much inconvenience the right spell can cause. And the most powerful wizards or sorcerers of all were always the old ones who spoke softly and politely while trying to look as frail and humble as possible. Or insane, as the great Merlin is so very good at fooling others into thinking him a buffoon.

So, with that in mind, what would one think of a spellcaster who traveled the world as an inconspicuous mouse? I almost burst into a fit of laughter. The poor man must have thought I were the most powerful magic user this side of the ocean. Perhaps I could bluff other people in such a fashion, if reluctant acceptance and compliance is the usual reaction then figuring out where I am and where to go should be easy.

But then, if the traveler hadn’t been so frightened as to run off in such a manor, I could have asked for directions as well. Peering down the street past the milling crowds, I saw no trace of him nor his ride. The smells of delicious, fresh food wafting down and around me drew my attention to more pressing … Step!

“SQUEAK!”

I felt something impossibly heavy crunching down my tail and let out a loud squeak in pain, but any noise I made was instantly drowned out by the ear shattering harpy screech from somewhere high above me. The weight flexed for a moment, grinding my tail into the pavement for good measure before kicking off. My spine arched, my hands reached for the base of my tail to try and stave off that dull ache, but that was the only comfort I would indulge myself while under attack.

I snarled. I curled my little fingers into tiny little mouse fists. I leapt back, noting the damage to my tail was painful but not extensive. I saw small flecks of blood surrounded by a footprint where my tail had just been

…

And then I looked up to see the foot.

Duh! I almost slapped myself for such stupidity. How had I missed the danger of standing in the middle of a sidewalk as this size?

“No harm d- …” I started to reassure my ‘assailant’ before hearing what was probably the most surprising sentence I had ever encountered.

“IT’S ANOTHER ONE! EVERYBODY, HELP! THE RATS HAVE STARTED ANOTHER WAVE!” she shouted in that shrill, shrieking sound that seemed to pound on my eardrums until I was inclined to beg for eardrums.

“ANOTHER ONE? Wait, why is there only one?” a man observing from a safe distance. He was not screaming as the woman who’d stepped on me, but his voice still thundered, rattling my bones with every syllable.

“It must be some super soldier, I heard their allies to the east guard the necronomicon.” yet another speculated. A small crowd formed completely of the curious grew whilst the fearful fled for a mix of help and shelter.

“HA! So they wish to fight darkly eh?” a proud looking man with a squat face and grizzly beard proclaimed while reaching for a weapon. “Such is the manor of cowardly rodents. I shall dispel any monstrosities they send my way! Be it through faith, or through blade!”

That was the moment I had to dodge. No time to think, no time to react, and certainly no time to try and reflect on all of this new information. A heavy sword, it’s blade thicker than I was tall, plummeted towards me. I shot to the left, held a paw up to protect my eyes and whiskers from a shower of sparks as metal ground on concrete, then assumed a defensive, agile fighting stance.

Looking past the first attacker I could see a row of uniformed and armored city guards marching towards the crowd. The metal of their spears gleamed in the midday sunshine.

There was little chance of fighting my way out of this. Well rested, well armed, and in human form I could manage such a challenge with only minor injuries. As a mouse? Unarmed? In a city that could very well have other, hidden defenses, or larger reserve forces waiting for this first wave to fall? This was an impossible fight.

But then, so was fleeing. The crowd surrounding me, the road with now halted traffic at my back, the buildings with nothing but solid stone and wood to hide in until I could run the full distance to an alleyway. If any of this crowd decided to simply stomp at random as I rushed through, one lucky shot would cripple me well enough to make the fallowing, finishing blow a simple matter of repeating that first hit. Escape, or hiding was almost as impossible as fighting.

If they were all calmer I could just try talking, explain what’s going on and ask what they have mistaken me for. But I can’t do that if I have to dodge spears and swords and feet. No, never mind, it’s too good of an easy card if it works, I’ll try to talk my way out no matter if I try to fight or run. The problem was deciding which course of action was the least impossible.

By the gods, I hated magic.
111111111.title: With a blank stare.

choices: Rush forward, get ahold of the paladin's beard.
1111111111.content:
I could never tell if it was fear or pride that made me decide to stand my ground. Escape looked impossible, but bold defiance seemed more natural for a long time guard. Besides, I didn’t have to win. Just survive long enough to make them stop fighting. Defense. I could handle defensive fighting.

“Please, sir, you are making a mis- …” I started to call out softly, politely, before leaping back as the point of a sword aimed strait for my chest.

“You think yer quick, aint ya little bugger?” my vulgar opponent accused whilst I tried not to let the small shower of crumbling cement spewing into my whiskers distract me. He lifted up one foot, leapt across the pavement like an overgrown child, and almost landed on my tail. I had to shoot towards my left to dodge the attack, but I always seemed to come within a hair’s breadth of dieing here. He missed only by millimeters, I could feel the gust of wind rush past me as he hit the pavement, my whiskers could touch his boots if I felt inclined to extend them.

“Stop this! We have no reason to …” his foot lifted up slightly, but aimed towards me once more and slammed down with incredible force before he could lift it up all the way. This blow came from much closer, was that much faster, and subsequently harder to dodge.

Thank whatever god who watches over mice for the fact I avoided that one, for surely I could not have managed on my reflexes alone. I dropped to all fours, figuring I could achieve better movement speed if I didn’t have to struggle for balance, then turned and ran as I saw the other leg shooting forward.

It didn’t lift up, nooooo … stomping would have been too easy to predict. This man used other leg to kick where I had dodged to in an attempt at an amusing punt. Yes, I thought it was amusing. I’d be lying if I said the thought of a flying mouse wasn’t a little bit funny. After covering three feet at a full run, I abruptly turned. I didn’t have any particular reason, but sudden and unexpec- …

CLASH!

Turns out I did have a reason after all, the man realized he could not reach me from there with his feet so thus used his sword instead. I was far away from the dust he sent flying and the small shower of sparks it summoned forth. It would be interesting if he managed to break that weapon before this fight was over. He clearly wasn’t holding back any force, and swords are not meant to slice through stone.

Unenchanted ones at least.

“Look at it go.” one man from the crowd gawked as I deftly avoided lethal blows.

“I wonder why it hasn’t made an attack yet. I keep hearing how dangerous the rat army is, but this one …” yet another commented.

“Unless it’s just a distraction, maybe? They do have an ‘Army’ after all, why would they send one rat?”

But I had little time to stop and answer such questions, or even figure out what to say. The beard faced man swiped his sword in a low arch this time, rather than slamming or stabbing as with his previous attempts. This not only made it harder to dodge, but more often than not each swipe was a good inch or so off the ground, no cement to slow it down or throw off his movements.

The first swing came from the left and carried through, which I dodged by rushing forward and ducking down low as it came over my head. My little mouse ears swiveled back against my skull, a practical gesture of fear that kept them from getting swiped off. The next blow came from the right, but swung upward at a diagonal angle. I had to jump backwards and to the left to avoid damage completely, if I had tried the same dodge I’d done before I would have been sliced in half.

Was the man smart enough to test me? Studying my moves and adapting his own accordingly? The next swipe came in low and from the left … very low. I jumped backward to avoid the blade itself, then jumped backward again and curled into a tight little ball of sanity as the screeching, scraping noise of metal through stone assaulted my ears. The air grew uncomfortably hot as sparks filled my line of sight. The light was too bright to see past for the brief moment it’s appearance was evidenced, like staring into the sun. His sword had swiped so low it clung to the ground and left a long gash through the sidewalk. The sword would not survive long if it were made of ordinary steel, but the results were worthwhile.

I uncurled much sooner than I’d wanted to, and rushed diagonally to my right before my vision had even cleared. It was a wise decision, as the chattering clang of metal at my previous location could attest to. No, this man was no amateur with that weapon. He might be severally misusing it, but he’d been trained in both the basics and the abstracts of sword fighting. You just could not get into a comfortable routine, he’d keep trying new things over and over until something catches you off guard. If I’d had a blade myself … and were roughly his size … this would have been an excellent battle.

“The whole west wing is panicked … over this?” I blinked and turned, looking at a uniformed city guard in a crude, copper helmet and serviceable chest-guard as it commented on the fight. There were five of them, all moving to surround both the street, the crowd, and the swordsman who seemed so enthusiastic about rodent extermination. The spears they wielded looked excellent against large, heavily armored foes, the weapon of choice when fighting a dragon or a troll.

But as a human … or, as a mouse … they just looked easy to dodge.

“Why is there only one?” one guard asked with a puzzled look on his face.

“Looks a bit scrawny to me. Are you sure that thing is a rat? Could just be a mouse.” every one of them had a voice like nearby thunder rumbling through a dragon’s belly. In other words, loud …

But the hairy man who’d been attacking all this time, voicing his outraged at such speculation, went above and beyond the levels of pain inducing volume any casual comment might induce. “ARE YOU ALL BLIND? Aint no ordinary mouse who can stand up to Nickolas Caoral fer more than a few seconds. Now as I hear it the rat army controls the Necronomicon, aint hard to suspect they usin it to boost their soldiers. I’ll bet this nasty bastard is just their trial run, lettim know how many babies they need to sacrifice to get an army of em. No, we kill the thing now and burn it‘s corpse so it can‘t ever come back”

“Um … sir … I’ll kindly ask you to step down. We will handle the incident from here, zombie rat or not.” one of them commented politely but sternly. Looking to the crowd he shouted. “Step away from the rodent, we don’t know what it can do or what it wants yet.” All of them seemed ready to fight if need be, but only the fuzz covered sword wielder seemed to have the air of homicidal crazy about him.

“Wha? I AINT Steppin back so long as this evil blights our fair streets, which in other words, means I’ll be steppin back in a second or two.” the fighter … Nickolas, apparently, announced before raising an empty hand to the sky. It glowed a white, flowing energy that seemed to twist and curl in on itself, before exploding across the crowd and radiating outward. Everywhere it hit life seemed to flourish, grass and flowers thirsting at the edges of the street shifted and grew, insects and ME! Seemed to flow with energy as the incarnation of life and goodness washed over us all.

That explains such zealousness … this man was a paladin! So long as he thought I was a monster, or even related to one, he’d stop at nothing to make sure my existence terminated. The light started to shine brighter and brighter, everyone cupped hands over their eyes to keep it from blinding them … now was the perfect opportunity.

I could rush forward, I knew right where my target was, and attack before the light faded. But then, all of the people crowing around were distracted as well, and even further apart. I would never get a better opportunity to run and hide than right now. But of course, by now I wanted answers. Answers I could only get by talking to those guards …

What would be the right thing to do?
1111111111.title: Fought my way out.

11111111111.content:
Rushing madly, blindly, I fallowed the sounds of boots grinding into pavement and heavy, labored breathing. My nose almost scraped against the ground, but with this light I could see neither. If I were not facing this paladin directly I doubt I could have ever found my way to … anything. At least for those few moments when the light was at it’s strongest, for now it was starting to fade.

I saw the outline of massive boots, legs the size of a castle tower, and I leapt. My front paws gripped the loose fabric while my back paws wrapped around for stability, then I bounced upward. Much like climbing a tree, I bounced with my hind legs, got a good grip all around, then immediately abandoned that grip for another few inches. The light was fading fast, my combatant was starting to react to my presence, but I had already made it to his shirt.

“GYAH!” He bellowed with that same earth shattering voice, like a dragons roar or a giant’s low shout, it rattled my bones as if I had been struck a thousand times over. I plowed through it, using buttons and waving fabric as my handholds now. He twirled and flailed to get me off, his sword dropped to the ground with a massive clatter, all of a sudden it became impossible to advance as my platform shifted in an unpredictable pattern. I held on tightly, I gritted my teeth, and I …

SMACK!

I flailed my arms as his hands swept across his chest, smashing into my face, then my neck, before ripping my arms loose and sending me falling towards the ground. My front pa- … hands! My front hands! Curled instinctively around one of his fingers, the only thing close enough to reach, and then the world rushed past as an incomprehensible blur. He panicked, his arm flailed, his hand and me went high over the man’s head and around in circles as he feverishly tried to shake me off.

Directly over his head, I let go … his hands continued to flail. I caught a glimpse of the city guards rushing in to offer their help. I saw the crowd of on looking peering as closely as they dared, to see what could have frightened such a boastful fighter. And then I saw the man’s hair rush past me. Then his eyes. Then his nose.

As the beard was within reach I gripped hard with one hand, felt a painful jerk as I decelerated, then brought my other hand around to lesson the load of my right one. I saw realization dawn on the man’s face, it was so close I could see the muscles working beneath his skin. Out of the corner of my eye I saw the flash of movement as his hands shot towards me … but they were too slow.

Gripping his beard with one hand, using my hind legs with a solid bracing on his chest, I leapt up as high as I could. Dragging the coarse, curly hair with me, I griped the hair of his head and strained to pull myself over. Thoroughly blinded, the man’s hands cupped and curled and slapped at random, his wailing had stopped now that something was covering his lips.

I took this opportunity of silence.

“ENOUGH! This battle is over!” I shouted at the top of my lungs, digging my heals into the smooth, sweaty skin of Nickolas’s forehead. “YIELD!”

At which point all commotion stopped. The paladin stood there, stunned. His spell had failed miserably, the law wanted to question me instead of kill me outright, and I had, in this brief moment, managed to overpower him.

If he decided to keep reaching for me I would be forced to escape lest I end up crushed between those massive hands, but everyone seemed too stunned by the prospect of a talking mouse to act. The next move anyone made, was by the same guard who realized I was much too small to be a rat.

“Could you repeat that? A little louder please.” he called politely. Stepping closer to both me and Nick. Probably to hear better. His voice was no less painful than anyone else’s, and it was difficult to maintain my hold when sound blasted at my ears so forcefully I grew dizzy. I shouted back as loud as I was able against at the command, but there was no way I could match that volume.

“I Said the battle is over! I come peacefully so long as he yields!” my nose pointed towards the paladin, who took this moment to come alive again. His hands smacked me from the side, I tore small tuffs of fur as I fell, but dropped it to grip the floppy sides of his shirt rather than take a bone breaking fall to that hard cement.

Not that such forceful jerking on my arms didn’t threaten to pull them from the socket.

“I can’t hear him. I think he said something about peace and … yield maybe? Either that or he wants to be a field.” the guard said, while another moved to restrain Nickolas. Strong hands cupped around me, lifted me up, up and away from that paladin.

“LET ME GO!” Nickolas bellowed. At that moment I was grateful for how well those thick fingers blocked all that horrible sound.

“Somebody cuff him, paladin or no when the commanding officer tells you to stand down you are supposed to STAND DOWN.” a voice answered, but I could not see who.

“On it boss” another responded. I sensed movement, then a few of the hands parted way, forcing me to look directly into an enormous set of dark blue eyes and pale skin. For a moment I could see every wrinkle, every crevice and imperfection, and then it was gone.

The man holding me indicated one of the other guards and called out …
11111111111.title: Rush forward, get ahold of ...

choices: I'm given a long time to think.
111111111111.content:
“Ronald, run and go get a cage for our captive.” his voice bellowing with the same incredible force as Nickolas. It was beginning to get annoying, these people were loud enough when talking normally, why were so many inclined to shout?

“Um, sir?” someone questioned from beyond the wall of fingers. Ronald's, presumably.

Someone nearby sighed heavily. “It’s in the caravan, top shelf on the left.” as if in answer to the unspoken question.

There was the sound of movement, of heavy footsteps on the pavement, fallowed by yet another incomprehensively loud bellowing.

“Everyone return to your homes, if something comes of this rodent the citizens will be notified. For now, there is nothing more to see.” then the world seemed to shift and shake, there was now a feeling of movement along with the sound.

Something nearby screamed in a muted tone, attempting to shout past some sort of muffle. The hands opened, I saw a brief glimpse of light, and then the world once more converged into darkness as the iron of a small cage clamped down around me. No, not complete darkness, I could see small beams of light reaching in through tiny air holes barely big enough to slip even my hands through. There would be no crawling out through there.

Wait, did I want to climb out? I wanted answers more than anything, I wanted to know where I was, what to do from here, and the more recent curiosity of why this town seemed so afraid of mice. Well, rats actually. That was one clue. If I tried to escape custody, I might never know. And, besides the cage, if I could simply sit down and explain what happened to me I might even get help finding my way home.

Surely this cage is simply a precaution, born from previous dealings with something more insidious than I could possibly be. Right?

The cage was tossed, presumably into the unseen caravan, as noted by the accompanying temporary loss of gravity fallowed by a painful crashing into the cage floor. It was not a gentle toss. I squeaked, more out of alarm than pain.

“Hey, be careful with that thing. Remember, for now its just a curiosity, not a war prisoner.” someone called out.

“For now being the operative words, mice are but one step removed from rats. It’s not hard to imagine they’d form an alliance.”

“Until you point out how often rats will eat mice.”

“Your point? That just gives the little buggers even more incentive to join! What army would eat away it’s own soldiers? I‘m willing to bet any smart mouse would try to join just for the immunity benefits.”

“Or, you know, flee. Mice are known to do that. Why stick around in a human city that rats seem determined to control?”

A completely knew voice chimed in, screeching just as loudly as all the others. “Will you two ingrates shut up? This …” I heard someone spit. “Rodent … is able to speak. You’ll all be briefed just as the rest of the populace if anything comes of this. Try not to get too exited, chances are it‘s just going to end up in Melson’s lab, dissected or made into some spell ingredient.”

It was at that point, I was sure I wanted out of this cage. I squeaked, I leapt at those little holes, I acted as cowardly as the mouse I looked like.

“What?!” And apparently I wasn’t alone in that outrage. “What do you mean, dissected? If it’s not any part of the rat army we shouldn’t treat it like an enemy. Especially if it knows how to talk. What if he has friends that are looking for him? What if mistreatment of this one mouse attracts vengeance from the rest of them? Heck, what if we blow the chance to make allies out of whatever species this little guy hails from? It would make the war that much easier if we had something able to find all the little rat holes and cracks in the foundation we would have otherwise missed.”

Someone there had big plans. Premature, perhaps, but imaginative. I relaxed a little, deciding to call out:

“MY NAME IS XANDER!” At the top of my lungs. I wasn’t awarded a response for my efforts.

“You need to get your head out of the clouds Ronald. I know you’ve got some pet rat, but don’t let the exception to the rule foo- …” the reprimanding was interrupted.

“My pet is a completely different kind of rat and you know it.”

“Who cares what kind it is, a rat is a rat.” a new voice joined in.

“Wait, since when do you keep one of those sewage covered things as a pet? That’s just … that’s just insane.” yet another new voice joined with it’s own comments.

“A couple weeks now.” the one called ‘Ronald’ defended. “And she does NOT bathe in sewage, contrary to popular belief.” I could hear the venom in this man’s voice, the same one who noticed I was a mouse and who now spoke out against possible injustice towards me.

“Lets change the subject, will yah? We’ll find out what the fuzzy little grey thing has to say during interrogation later. I for one, am more interested in how Nickolas is going to take imprisonment.”

“Bah, that’s just cus your new here Sergis. The old fart ends up in jail for minor charges at least once a month! He’ll just rattle the cage and rail on and on about disrespect or the god’s wrath or some other stupid thing.”

“Hehe! Oh that reminds me, if you really want to make the fat man squirm, ask him ‘which god’ whenever he starts preaching. He always seems to forget that there’s more than one, and around here not all of those gods are nice.”

“Huh, you know, I’d consider taking you up on that plan but I’d rather have my genitals remain attached, thank you. I heard those rumors about what he did t- …”

“ENOUGH!” the loud, thundering voice of the commander broke through the conversation like a fireball spell through a house of paper. “Ronald, you go take your mouse friend into the interrogation chamber, explain what you can to Groff when ye get there. The rest of you, help escort ‘sir’ Nickolas to his chambers and then get back out on patrols.”

I listened closely, unable to see anything outside my cage.

“Yes sir” answered a chorus of guards, before strong hands lifted my cage up gently and moved me around to … somewhere. The only thing I could make out from these movements were that whoever made them had enough care to keep me from tossing around.

“Ronald, I want you to stay behind and carry the little pest wherever Warden Groff wants him put. Do you understand soldier?”

“Sir, yes sir.” Was the answer, spoken in a soft and calm tone.

“Well get a move on then” the commander’s tone was just as polite. That seemed, odd. “Lets just hope nothing else interesting happens.”

A distant voice commented on that with a chuckle “A boring day is a safe day”

Fallowed an even more distant “Amen to that”

And then it all went silent, save for Ronald’s breathing and the smashing of heavy boots onto old but sturdy wood.
111111111111.title: Get the cage!

choices: Don't worry, I'll get back in the cage.
Oh come on, I'm a mouse! I'm not that dangerous.
1111111111111.content:
The cage swung, back and forwarth, steadily but slowly as Ronald made his way through hallways I could barely glimpse, past people of whom I could see no more than the sides of their legs. I tried to listen in as closely as possible, even without talking I was getting some rather useful information from the previous conversation. But people don’t generally talk when they are alone, and Ronald seemed to be on his own while carrying the cage.

That gave me time to think, but even more time to realize how much pain I was in. My spine still hurt, just not as much as before I took that nap. My skull wasn’t throbbing anymore, but the headache remained. These people were just way too loud. The worst of it was my tail, oh gods my tail hurt. I didn’t have much light to see by, and my eyes weren’t supper impressive that could see through the dark with ease, but I could tell I was bleeding.

Not bleeding out, there wasn’t even a slight risk of passing out from blood loss, but unless it heals fast or I get some cover there was the mild concern of infection. I rubbed my hands across my haunches, those flabby thigh areas around my butt, and felt for the base of my tail. Once I found that it was easy to feel along the length of it for the battered and crushed area that some passerby had stepped on. It literally was flatter than the rest of the tail. The skin, and parts of the flesh, had been ground off and pulverized by sheer weight.

Now that I didn’t have the adrenaline needed for a fight, it was harder to suppress the pain. I was going to have to ask for some alcohol, and then a strip of cloth or something. This needed to be treated.

My stomach then decided it was time to compete with my tail for attention, I was still starving. Food, good food at least, was no highly unlikely. Who would waste good food on a prisoner? Who would waste good food on a mouse? Yeah, stupid luck on my part. I turn into a rodent and wind up walking through a town literally at war with them.

As a human I knew my body could go three days without food before doing anything useful became impossible. But only one day before doing anything useful became really, really hard. As a mouse I had absolutely no idea. Would my training even come into play? Probably, seeing as I still had decent reaction time and knew how to make a fist. Didn’t change the fact I was still hungry.

I scurried over to the edge of the cage, looking up and out through those tiny little holes. From this angle I could see the roof, and I could see part of the arm that held my cage. The roof looked bleak and dark, propped stone held by a framework of ageing, petrified wood. A sturdy setup for a dungeon, and with enough mortar between each and every peace of material to make crawling through impossible. Was the whole place really set up to be mouse proof? That seemed likely.

I stood on my hind legs, though quickly realized the gentle swaying cage was impossible to balance in without staying on four legs. So I leaned against the side and dug my little paws into the air holes, using that grip to hold me upright. I sniffed the fresh air with my little mouse nose, I twitched cutely with my little mouse whiskers …

And I squeaked pathetically with my little mouse lungs as gravity seemed to vanish, I found myself propelled up to the roof of the cage, then violently slammed downward. I couldn’t just let me land on the floor, nope, that would have been too simple. As I was falling and bracing for impact, the whole cage twirled around so that the wall smacked me from the side. It landed on the ground with an annoying clatter, I heard a wet “Thud!” as Ronald landed flat on his chest.

The joints of the cage creaked and groaned, the whole thing seemed to be on it’s edge and just about to tip over. I rushed towards the other wall, LEAPT! With that awesome mouse leaping abilities I’d experienced with that whole horse tail incident, then held a solid grip with both arms jammed through tiny air holes as the metal box fell over again.

Metal grinded against metal which in turn, smashed against stone. It was hell on my ears, but I had to stay alert as evidenced by two of the cage’s nails falling off. Or maybe the cracked? Either way nothing was holding up the wall I hung from, leaving me with that eerie feeling of vertigo when it fell off. I pulled my arms out quickly, squinted my eyes against the harsh, but still dark light of the room, and braced my feet as best I could when …

SLAM!

The metal wall smashed into the floor with me riding it like a giant, stiff, magic carpet. Ok, more like a solid wall crashing down with some idiot hanging on the whole time. My feet stung, but everything else was uninjured. Much to my relief. And finally I had a chance to see the hallway I’d been taken to. Not room, hallway. There was a door, much too solid and low to the floor for even a mouse to squeeze under, roughly ten feet in the direction we’d been traveling. The walls were a mix of heavy stones and well placed, four inch thick logs for support. The roof was flat and solid, and about nine feet tall. Way out of my reach.

Looking around past the now broken and bent mouse cage, I saw an almost identical door ten feet in the opposite direction, also along a flat, boring hallway. Both doors looked sturdy. Thinking about it tactically, even without any magic surprises, this would be a perfect choke point in case of any large scale invasion. Be they prisoners escaping, or an army trying to hold this place as a fort. But it was still boring.

I saw Ronald starting to get up, I saw the bright red eyes covered in part by muddy blonde hair, and I saw a mixture of curiosity and terror in the man’s face as he spotted me. Free. Out in the open, with no witnesses around and no one to help him fast enough should I have super attack hidden under my fur like they all seemed to think.

He scrambled to his knees, grabbed the main portion of the cage with one hand while ignoring the little scraps that had fallen off. I scurried quickly off of the cage wall under my feet, looked towards the door, considered my options …

I smiled as best I could with my little mouse muzzle, saying …

11111111111111.content:
“Don’t worry about it, I’ll get back in the cage” as loudly, and with as much force as my weak little lungs could manage. The young man blinked, and I swear that was a loud blink, before asking with that same thundering tone as before.

“What?!”

I groaned, one hand raised aiming to cover my ears, but I held it off. This time I didn’t bother sounding polite, I just screamed. Full of rage, full of anger, with that shrill vibration you just know you can feel whenever a captain issues a command. I used the sort of voice you have to use on a battlefield to make yourself heard over the clatter and cheering a thousand or more men.

“I’LL JUST GET BACK IN THE CAGE!” He seemed surprised. Or at least I think he did. He stood up carefully, bending his knees so that he kept at a crouch. Making sure he kept his eyes on me, that I didn’t do anything without him seeing it.

He pondered the cage for a moment, looked down to me, then set the broken metal box inches from my face. I felt the wind brush my ears and whiskers back across my head, I felt the rush of air pressure as such a massive object landed so close to me. But nothing hurt, and it didn’t keep moving after he set it down, so I readily climbed in and waited for the man to pick it up.

He did so, with just as much care and attention as he’d used before. Balance really wasn’t an issue, up until the guy tripped it was a smooth ride. Holding me up with one hand, he then bent down to reach the rest of the metal scraps and broken wall. He turned his head to give me a sidelong glance, took a few steps carrying everything, then expectedly burst into curiosity.

“What are you, exactly?” he asked with a voice like distant thunder.

“A mouse! I think” I was tilting my head to look up towards his face, keeping all four legs braced against the metal ‘floor’ just in case he tripped again. This time there was a giant hole in the cage, meaning it’d be easier to fall out. Looking down, I also got the feeling I could jump out if given half a chance.

“Um, can you … can you speak up or something? It’s very hard to hear you.” this time he was quieter. Still sounded like someone talking through speakerphone spell, but it didn’t make me long for some form of ear covering.

I thought for a moment, if he could not hear me from this position no matter how loud I shouted then why waste my breath shouting? Well, he could hear me, just not well enough to understand everything. Why was that? The guy on the horse could speak with me just fine, he didn’t even have that mountain voice everyone else seems to have. Then it hit me, the guy on the horse couldn’t hear me either, I had to climb up to his ear. Smiling, I answered Ronald by standing up on two legs, then tapping my left ear.

“Wha … oh! Yeah I get it.” a sudden change in momentum and I was knocked flat on my back. Scrambling up to my feet, all fours this time, I looked out the hole right into the man’s face. Weird to look at a man and actually see the layers of sweat and grime that coat his forehead, horrible to see individual pores in his skin that just oose a nasty, salty water like some giant slime monster. The smell, oh gods the smell, it was even worse than the horse. How dragons could stand eating these things I will never understand. But this should be close enough to talk to him.

“Can you hear me now?” I asked experimentally.

“Y-yes, I can actually” the man’s eyes widened.

“Excelent. Now do be careful not to drop the cage again, please. I fear I would not be lucky enough to get off without injury a second time”

The man blinked, looked downcast, then immediately shifted to suspicious. “Without injury, what did you not notice your tail or something? We’ve got to get that bandaged.”

I squeaked … er, laughed! Ok, I tried to laugh, it just came out as a squeak. “I didn’t forget, I just didn’t get that wound from the fall. It is my reminder that standing on a sidewalk is not wise for one’s health.”

“Oh, so then you got that … what, in the fight with old Nick? That makes sense, the man’s got wicked eyes and killer aim. I haven’t known anyone to spar with him to get off without at least a cut.”

“No-no, the paladin never touched me despite coming close. This wound is from some woman who stepped on my tail.”

Ronald stared at me. Blinking hard. Was there something about me just that hard to believe? Well, the paladin was a good fighter. Perhaps the thought of a mouse besting him, even in some small way, was just to incredulous to overlook.

I heard a ripping sound, like someone tearing fabric, which was immediately fallowed by a large, brown strip of cloth thrust into the cage next to me. Apparently changing the subject.

“There you go, I’ll try to get that tied on as soon as …”

But I was already wrapping it tight around my wound, a crude but serviceable tourniquet that should … I sniffed it. That should make me smell like human sweat, because that’s what it was doing. Hard to believe that strip of cloth somehow smelled worse than my exposed butt.

“I thank you good sir, but there is no need for such.” I think I surprised him. The man sure looked surprised as I heard the soft creaking of a door opening, saw the room widen and flatten into a smaller square as we exited the hallway, and then the loud ‘thud’ of my cage crashing onto a small table. Nothing broken, nothing was dropped, it was just loud.

I crawled out, looked to see a room that was, save for a table much too high to jump down from, empty. Ok, maybe I could have tried, but it went up to a man’s chest. Ronald could not have sat in a chair and still be able to look at me. Surely I would at least break my legs attempting the jump. I offered a sidelong glance over to the human who carried me in, then scurried over to the edge of the table.

I looked down at the corners, mice could climb exceptionally well, but they still needed something to hold onto. The table’s legs were smooth, solid metal, shiny from frequent polish, and was smaller towards the floor than at the actual connection. Impossible to climb down without a rope. Was this table specifically designed to hold rodents?

“Don’t bother trying to get down, this is an interrogation room and we aren’t new to this sort of thing.” Ronald calmly explained.

I crawled my way over to him, nodded slightly, and responded. “Not trying to escape, just curious. I’ve never seen something like this before, the thought of humans engaging in active war with mice just seems ridiculous.”

“Not mice, Rats.” He corrected. “Much bigger than you, and perfectly capable of killing a man when you give them a chance to swarm. Never known a mouse to speak Uema either … how exactly did you learn it?”

He was busily picking the cage up and placing the scraps of metal inside so the whole of it was easier to carry as I started to answer, only to be interrupted by …
