111111111111111.content:
SLAM!

Words on a page cannot possibly describe how loud that sound was. If one were to write in massive letters, with a single letter covering a complete page and a plethora of symbols in the background to indicate displeasure or force, it would still not have been an apt description. My head felt ready to split apart, my bones, my spine especially, gave way so that I fell on my belly. My ears, the soft inner portions that made up the extended fleshy bits vibrated noticeably. Yet for all it’s terror, the sound lasted no longer than a single moment.

I didn’t even have time to cover my ears.

“Good morning, s-sir! The p-prisoner … is …” Ronald seemed to stutter, I looked up from my tiny little world of hurt to see him pointing towards me. Evidently the man was shaken up as well, but clearly not as much as me. Finding the energy to talk, or point, while my head throbbed in such a manor was beyond comprehension.

I decided that so long as I was not doing anything else, I might as well look towards whomever Ronald had addressed. Turning my head I saw a slim, well built man in a green tunic, I could see small slivers of chainmail shining through at the thighs and shoulders. Though the clothing was covering much of it. He had dark hair, pale white skin, and piercing green eyes. The man had eyes that seemed to study you from the moment they saw you, perceptive, scanning for any trace of weakness.

And then his hand reached over to slam the door …

For a split second I panicked, having to deal with that sound for a second time was just too much. I scrambled for the nearest cover, which happened to a bent nail sitting on the table, much too small to actually cover anything. My ears swiveled low onto my skull, my arms shot up to hold them down tighter and block the ear-hole directly. I knew it was merely a token gesture when the vibrations were painful even through my fur, but anything that could lessen the pain was worth the effort.

The man’s arm pushed gently and quietly, all I heard was a click as the door shut and some lock held it in place. I was relieved. The green clothed man looked curiously at me, then inspected the room. His eyes noticeably aiming towards Ronald, then the table, then the scraps of metal, and finally that broken cage. His face twisted in mild anger, mild comprehension, to which Ronald responded with fear.

“Oh! Y-yes sir, my apologies about the cage, I w-will go send to have th-this fixed.” my transport stammered. Cradling the whole thing in his arms while pacing towards the door.

“Bring a working one.” the man said, his voice both monotone and quiet. This was the first time in a long time someone could talk without blasting sound at me. The man sounded normal! “On your way back.”

“Y-yes, master Felast.” and with that Ronald scurried out the door as fast as his legs could carry him. He’d left a few scraps of metal, that bent nail at my feet and the chunk of a corner that had somehow rusted off. But otherwise I was completely exposed on a wide, barren desk.

Alone in the room with me, one way out, the human named ‘Felast’ apparently, regarded me calmly while walking towards the table. He placed both his hands behind his back, stood with his chest just inches from the side of the table, and all the while kept his eyes on me. It was very hard to focus on anything except those sharp, green eyes. We stood in silence for a few moments that seemed to drag on in a perverse manner. But I actually shivered when he spoke.

“I am Felast. The interrogator. Who are you.” the man managed to make a question sound like an order. He was quick, he was quiet, he seemed determined to use as few words and as short a sentence as possible. I just stood there staring at him before realizing I’d need to talk.

“My name, is Xander!” I shouted at the top of my lungs, knowing from past experience that anything less would be impossible to hear. At this the man glared, fierce and frightening … I thought he was about to attack.

“Do not shout.” another three word sentence, fallowed by “Who are you aligned with Xander.”

I blinked, then answered in what felt like a normal voice. Certainly not whispering, but not shouting either. “I have pledged my allegiance to Reginald Finnly, king of the Iron wall regions.”

“Of what race.” apparently he’d heard me. Was his hearing just that good? Or was some unseen enchantment aiding conversation? Either way I was confused.

“What do you mean? what race am I allied with? Well I think that’s …”

“Of what race is your king.” he corrected. A little more forcefully.

“Human.”

“Why are you allied with a human king.” his eyes narrowed, he seemed to grow suspicious.

“Because I am human.”

Felast’s eyes widened in shock, then narrowed again in disbelief. “You are awfully short for a human.”

I stood up onto two legs, started to speak, and was immediately stopped by a large finger poking against my chest.

“And you need a shave.” I blinked … still monotone, it was difficult to decide if he meant that as a joke or actually believed it.

“Please let me explain.” I squeaked out, though the hand didn’t smell anywhere near as horrible as my previous close up with a human body part, it was still intimidating.

“Please do.”

“I was a human guard on a late night watch, protecting the king of the Iron Castle. We were caught unawares by a wizard in dark garbs, me and six others, who tore through our defense as if we were children. He dodged enchanted weapons faster than the eye could fallow, and those attacks which did land he ignored outright. I charged him from behind, attempting to grapple and hold him down … but he cast an offhand spell, leading to my current predicament.”

“And then what” Felast didn’t bat an eye to my story.

“I woke up in a wooded area near … wherever this place is, I do not know the names of this area and cannot say. I procured a ride on a horse from a passing traveler, fell asleep for I am not sure how long, and got off for …” my stomach interrupted me with a rather annoying grumbling, I still hadn’t had a bite to eat in roughly a day. “For something to eat. But a passing villager stepped on my tail.” I demonstrated by pointing towards the bandaged area.

“And then what.”

“Then the panic that you are no doubt aware of occurred. I was attacked by the paladin Nickolas, and chose to go with the city guards willingly.”

“Why.” again, simple questions.

“Because I have great respect for the guards of a city, I had assumed doing so would help me figure out why this town is afraid of rodents. And perhaps seek out much needed aid from sympathetic people.”

“I see.” the man’s eyes narrowed. I hadn’t learned anything useful so far, I was still starving, and I had no way to tell if this man believed me or not. He raised one hand, glanced over to the door with furious eyes, and then …

1111111111111111.content:
He shouted “Come in” with the same gigantic sonic blast everyone else seemed to apply to their voice. Reminding me once again that while soft spoken and attentive, Felast was still much, much larger than me at the moment.

The door opened quietly enough for my poor sensitive ears, and Ronald walked in carrying a duplicate of the cage he’d dropped.

“I have the ca-" The man started to mutter

“I see that.” Felast interrupted. He then turned his attention back to me stating “What sort of aid do you expect? Do you intend to beg us for food or drink?” which was probably the longest sentence I’d heard him say this entire time.

“While either would be appreciated if offered I would much rather ask for a magician or sorcerer who can return me to normal. I do not have any money at the moment thanks to the fact I can’t carry much of it, but once human again I can work to pay off whatever I owe.” I didn’t bother shouting this one and noticed Ronald struggling to make out my words as a result, but Felast and his sharp senses could understand me perfectly.

“Ronald.” he directed in a cold tone. “cage Xander once more.”

“Yes sir.” Ronald blinked, walked over to the table and then set the cage down on it’s side.

“I know the routine.” I stated before climbing in and hugging the back wall to avoid falling on my side when the cage flipped. As it did so, the wall became the floor, the lid slid in place, and I was once more surrounded by darkness.

“Take him to Melson.” Felast stated, at which point my cage started to swing and shake before finally stabilizing. This didn't bother me as I could balance just fine.

“Why would … erm, alright then.” Ronald seemed worried, confused, and just a small bit … sad? Why would there be sadness in his voice. I wasn’t able to see out and the cage didn’t transfer much movement, so when the door swung open with that annoying creaky sound I was surprised. Just as I was starting to wonder about that tone of voice Felast called out to Ronald …

“Tell him we suspect that mouse is under enchantment. It’s his job to rid the creature of it.”

Ronald blinked, turning sharply enough to make me slide on my feet towards the sides of the cage. “What sort of enchantment?”

"Creature?" I questioned in annoyance.

“Ask him.” I heard Felast walk through a doorway himself, then saw a bright, annoying light as the cage roof opened up.

“Is that how you can talk?” Ronald asked, curious.

“NO!” I shouted back with growing ire, shaking my head vigorously.

“Ah, so then what sort of enchantment little mouse? No wait, let me guess, your immortal. That’s how you lasted so long against Nick.”

I shook my head again, my whiskers twitching animatedly.

“Not immortal? Ok, well it has to be some combat related thing. Super speed perhaps?”

Again, I shook my head. If he’d just lean closer and pay attention the conversation would be over a lot faster. But then, if he leaned too close and forgot to watch where he was going he could trip again. Or, you know, crash into a wall.

Ronald sighed “I guess I’ll figure it out when we reach Melson. I really hate being left in the dark here. You and Felast don’t talk very much.” and with that he slid the roof back over my cage, and I was consumed by darkness.

"I sort of wish you'd fallow his example." I muttered with my ears twitching up and down. I could try to get used to it, but my god were these voices loud.

I still hadn’t had a meal, and my stomach was complaining avidly, but there was not a lot I could do about that. Not a lot I could look at either from within the dark confines. I could smell just fine, I could tell we were walking through the streets because the smell of people’s dinner drifted lazily through the air. Eliciting just the tiniest bit of drool to slip past my chin … I was so hungry. The smell of fresh air, the moisture of approaching nightfall, and the stench of human sweat didn’t do much to distract me from the thought of food.

Food … apples. Apple pie. Roast chicken. Steak. Even old, crusty bread with no flavoring seemed appetizing at the moment. I idly wondered how much rum it would take to render me a blathering fool. But then again, at this size, even a small cup of fine wine or sweet Champagne would last me a week!

I sighed. Thinking about ways to fill my belly or just how much food was available to a small creature could not be the most useful ways to spend one’s time. But what else? Ronald wasn’t the best for conversation considering his difficulty hearing me. I could not see the sights, not that I would have seen anything new or useful. Maybe I could spend this time focusing on my new body? Couldn't hurt to at least make sure it works right.

I decided to curl my tail around, reaching a hand out to feel across the now blood-soaked bandage. My soft, grey fur needed cleaned … that much was certain. But would I be able to find a bath soon? Er, I’ve never seen mice swimming or bathing in anything. Exactly how did they clean themselves? I know they’d have to at some point, a smelly prey is prey that’s easy to find, surely any mouse would know that.

Maybe it's supposed to snap off or something? Some lizards have detachable tails, does it work the same way with mice? Experimentally I gripped the very base and gave a light tug. Unsurprisingly my only reward was a sharp pain in the rear. Ok, so it's not supposed to snap off. I could wash it off in a tub or something, perhaps a small cup. I'll need to wash the bandage too, lest diseases begin to fester.

My thoughts were then distracted as a door opened, I’m not really sure what door it was or just where we were, but I know some door opened. The miniscule lighting from my air holes shifted, the smells of food faded away under a blanket of herbs, dust, and mold. I stood on two legs, raised my nose to the air, then shivered.

I could smell death. I could smell horror, and pee, and food going to rot. I could smell the iron scent of blood as it spills out corpses and mats onto the floor, none of which was especially strong. It was … distant. Like the source of the scent was present, but hidden. It sent shivers down my spine.

I heard a thump as Ronald set the cage down, probably on a table, then covered my ears as he screamed out in that thundering voice of his.

“Hello! I’ve got a new customer for you Melson!” nothing happened at first, so we both waited. And waited. And waited.

…

“Coming!” a grunt sounding, harsh voice called from somewhere bellow. I heard the thumps of a fat man on molding wooden boards, I heard the creaking of stairs threatening to give way, and I heard the same painfully loud voice from Melson as I did from most everyone else. “Who is it th- … OH! Hohoho, another specimen for me to study?”

I squeaked in freight as the cage shifted under a careless inspection. Light burst into my eyes as the lip opened up, causing me to blink. A fat, pudgy little hand that smelled of blood and death reached down for me, which I deftly avoided.

“No Bottle-lord Melson, it is a customer. Lord Felast has requested you remove a curse placed upon this mouse.”

I could see melson’s frustration at his failure to catch me, then he regarded Ronald and said …

11111111111111111.content:
“Now hold on a minute, let me study this thing a little while.” Melson growled as his chub filled hand reached for me a second time. I squealed in discomfort at rough fingers curled around my head and spine, there wasn’t a great deal of room to maneuver. It was not pleasant, made in part by the fact he did not seem to care about handling. So far the only time’s I’ve been picked up has been careful and gentle, but this guy squeezed my face into my shoulders while leaving my legs and tail dangling.

I felt a sharp pinch at the tip of my tail, had but a moment to realize what was coming, then screamed. Melson dropped my head, letting his grip on my tail alone hold me up. My entire body now held by that single, thin appendage, the rapid change in support caused my now free falling head to swing down. All of this added pressure was focused on that wound … it’s not hard to tell why I screamed.

“ARGH!” blood spurted out as the wound opened much, much wider than it had been originally, even when I was first stepped on. The cloth turned bright red as it absorbed more than it could handle, I felt my own blood trickling down past my thighs and dripping onto my belly. My muscles spasmed as I struggled to stay alert through the pain.

“Wow! Careful with him, can’t you see he’s hurt?” someone called out, but it was hard to tell who. The voice was just as loud and rumbling as every other time, and it was so hard to focus while upside down and screaming. Immediately after I felt a soft, gentle support at my head, then the pressure at my tail released. I was breathing hard, looking at the two giants with mild distain over that sudden mistreatment …

They weren’t giants, they were humans, so I should stop … no! I will not call the fat man human, so far as I’m concerned he didn’t deserve that honor. But I felt curling my tail around to nurse two wounds, both the footprint and where I’d been pinched, was more useful than cursing them out. I carefully removed the bandaged, cringed at the sight of a now exposed scar, much more damaged than it was just a few moments ago. Blood dripped down onto the hand I was held in, Ronald’s, obviously, for it was not covered in fat. I then straitened out the cloth strip, rung it out as best I could …

And was stopped before I could wrap it back on.

“Remarkable! I’ve never seen a mouse do such a thing, oh but do stop it. That silly strip will just get in the way, and rodents have a tough immune system.” Melson, of course.

“I erm …” Ronald seemed to think it over. “You’ve got a bottle of whisky right there, at the very least disinfect the wound.” he demanded.

“Why bother?”

“Oh come on, it’s not like it’d be out of your way.”

“Still doesn’t explain why I should …” Melson was cut off as Ronald just grabbed the bottle himself and carefully dripped some onto the tail. It splashed about in his hand, mixed with the very small pool of blood, and lapped over my legs and thighs. I flinched at the pain, tensing up as it seemed like one torture piled on top of another, but this one I saw coming and this one was necessary. I had no complaints.

“Thank you” I called out as loudly as I could manage through gritted teeth.

“Hey! What are you …” Melson interrupted.

“You’re supposed to remove his enchantment, not tear his tail off. Lord Melson. And you are going to do just that.”

Melson blinked a moment, seemed to ponder his options, then sighed. “Exactly what sort of enchantment does it have then?”

This time it was Ronald who blinked. “He, uh … what was it again.” he held me up to his ear and waited for an answer. I was starting to get annoyed by how often I was jerked around.

“I am actually a …!” but I didn’t get to finish the sentence, let alone make sure anyone could hear it.

Melson saw this as an opportunity and smiled. “Ohhohoh, don’t bother. I’m a skilled magic user you know, just hand the little guy over and I’ll figure it out myself.”

“Er, uh …” I was forcibly snatched out of Ronald’s hands. The man, apparently, was not very good at thinking on his feet. The room seemed to shift and swerve, fat enveloped my chest and stomach, and the next thing I could see was Melson’s face. This was the first time I’d actually paid attention to it. He had dark hair, light brown eyes, and very round cheeks that made him look childish. Infantile. Though as I saw him smile, that face took on the overall appearance of evil.

“Now lets see here … hmmm-OH! This creature is a shape shifter!”

“What?” Ronald blinked again, considering the blood and alcohol on his hand before wiping them onto his shirt.

“Or maybe it’s been shape shifted. Much less entertaining than a creature that changes at will. Oh how I’d love to look into such magics! The ability to change sizes or species, even changing appearances in subtle ways to bring out inner beauty. What I wouldn’t give to be able to trim away all this fat and strut through the town young and handsome.” his palms started to sweat, and that sweat soaked into my fur. The smell wasn’t nearly as bad as the salt it dripped into my open wound.

“Er, Ooook … sure, that sounds useful. But what about the …”

Once again melson cut him off. “Right, right. Lets get started then.” he placed me onto the table, shoved aside several papers and at least one empty bottle. He placed both his hands over me in a dramatic pose, presumably calling forwarth whatever magic he’d need to remove this curse and return me to my proper form. Heck, if the fat, unpleasant magician succeeded with this spell I might actually refrain from punching him over what he’d done to my tail.

His hands flashed bright blue for a moment, then faded away with the speed of a shooting star. I could feel my fur slip away, I could feel myself growing, I could even feel my whiskers vanish, but then it all came back in a tidal wave of screaming, monstrous agony. Each individual hair was like a dagger sprouting from my skin! It felt just like the initial spell that got me! I collapsed to my side, too much pain, too fast to handle it, on top of the emotional trauma involved with feeling that trace of humanity slip away before my eyes.

By the time the pain was gone, I was unchanged. Still a small, grey mouse.

“Can’t reverse it. Sorry but whoever did this is way stronger than me, it’s not just a single transformation spell. He’s cursed in such a way that every moment of his life the spell that initially transformed him is recasting itself. I’d have to come up with something completely new to battle this kind of creative spell casting. Your talking work for a master!”

I could not help but mutter “By the gods, I hate magic.”

111111111111111111.content:
“So, wait, you mean you can’t remove this curse then? We have to hire a someone else?” Ronald asked, trying to take everything in. I was too busy trying to stay conscious to pipe in with my own concerns.

“Hohohoh! You’d have to get a completely different caliber of magician, boy. I’m talking someone with the power to summon meteor storms, enough magic to decimate an entire kingdom! Whoever cast this spell did so at a permanent cost to their total spell pool! In theory one could remove the curse by killing the original caster, but that’d be even harder than creating an anti-spell.”

“I have no idea what that means."

“Of course not" Melson sighed, reaching a hand down to pick me up none too gently. “To cure this creature myself, I’d need to cast a spell that constantly reverts him to his natural form just as often as the current curse traps this thing in the body of a mouse. Not only would that be at a permanent cost to my total spell casting abilities, but it’d take more magic than I actually have! If you ever need to repeat that to your superiors, just say it’s long, complicated, and expensive. I’ll work on it.”

“Ok then.” Ronald balked. Glaring slightly at how I was held. “But what was he before? Do you know what the original form was?”

“Of course I do, human! Wouldn’t waste this sort of power on a toad now would you?”

“Wha, human!? Then why are we keeping him in a cage!” Ronald burst.

“He’s not human now, is he? A cage is probably safer than anything else we can carry him in.”

“There is such a thing called dignity.”

“Bah! The man was probably a barbarian savage, or some street urchin who begged the wrong person for food. Don’t worry about it boy, worrying is not going to make things any easier.” Melson stated condescendingly … at the same time carrying me over to the cage I’d come in on. I had barely even gotten to examine the room, and already I was placed back into darkness!

“I still don-"

“You just go on home, I’ll handle things from here on out. These are complex magics, and surely you could not hope to comprehend them well enough to help. Even in the slightest.”

“My shift isn’t over, I still have to …”

“Then go report this mouse’s whereabouts, I’ll let the captain know if anything turns up from my research here. So far as it concerns you, this little mouse is, well, no longer a concern.”

“After how I’ve just seen you handling this ‘mouse’ I’ll think not. I can watch over the little fella better than you can, you have rows upon rows of rodent habitat and hundreds of different subjects to care for. I only have one pet, and as such can focus on him.”

“What does that have to do with anything? You don’t know how to cast magic and you don’t have the mental capacity to do anything along the lines of scientific inquiry. I doubt you can even read.”

There was an odd silence. I could not see any facial expressions, a pattern that was beginning to annoy me, but I could just tell there was severe hostility in the air.

“Fine” Ronald decided, I heard some rather dainty footsteps as he walked out, fallowed by a muted slam. I covered my ears to guard against that sound, but was immediately shoved back onto four feet as the cage wobbled and swayed.

I could see through the airholes to tell that I was moving. The walls shifted, the lighting changed to a darker tone, and … and …

By the gods! The smell was horrible! As soon as Melson’s overweight body crunched onto a moldy stairway the scent that had only offered a hint of death soon overwhelmed every other detail. It smelled like a morgue. No, it didn’t smell that nice, it smelled more like someone had torn the walls and roof off a morgue, used that place for a battlefield, and then decided to leave the bodies piled up rather than burry anyone.

It wasn’t just the smell of people dieing and blood clotting in the dry air, it was all that and more combined with the smell of fresh zombies and necromancer farts. I squeaked in fright as the cage roof opened up and those fat, pudge filled hands came for me. There was no way out and no where to run, my only real option was to let him grab me.

As soon as I was out of the cage I looked around in Melson’s hidden laboratory. I was sure it was a hidden, underground laboratory because this room didn’t look anything like the previous one. The lighting was bad in most areas, but shockingly bright in the center of the room thanks to some clearly magical lantern. There was a huge, metal table directly under the light, filled with blades, bottles and various metal wires. There were shelves lining the walls, in which the one in he far back was overflowing with containers of bodily fluids, bright red or glowing liquids, herbs, plants and trinkets of every sort. Every other shelf was filled with clear, glass cages housing hundreds of rodents.

Hundreds.

Of every size, color and shape imaginable while still mouse like enough to qualify as a mouse. Some were black, some were a pure white, some were grey, and a good portion were brown. Every one of them looked and smelled horrible, miserable, like they’d been living in squalor for the duration of their stay. Worse still, much to the distain of my newly acquired mousey hearing, I could hear every one of them screaming … they sounded exactly like I’d expect a human to sound, no squeaking or little chitter noises, they shouted and I understood it as Uema.

Most didn’t make any sound.

He slid a metal tablet into position with his one free hand, reached for some of the metal wire I’d seen before, and continued talking to himself.

“You’ll be an entertaining one to study. If someone does manage to cast a specific counter spell you’d have the ability to switch back and forwarth from one to the other at will. You’d literally exist in two separate states at the same time, allowing you to be either or both! It’s the ultimate in instantaneous shape shifting! If I could crack the idea behind it and secure enough energy to cast it, I could … well I could …”

The man’s rude, round little face delight as he dreamed up the possibilities, and I shivered. His hand placed me back first onto the tablet. Well, it didn’t so much place me, as slap me down and hold me tight enough that I could not readjust. I felt pain, naturally, and was starting to think I’d be feeling it often from now on. I knew I had mouse teeth, and I knew his hands were just within reach … but then I also knew, full well, that I could not be the first rodent to try and bite him. Save my defiance for a time when it’d actually be useful.

I glared at the man when his hand slipped away, started to get up onto my feet, and then panicked as something strong and unyielding held my arm down. I blinked, looked over to see the tiny little wire bent around my wrist, and shouted in a mix of rage and terror.

“The hell is- ACK!” in a flash, another one was placed around my neck, wrapping me to the tablet quite nicely. I reached my free hand up to the metal and started to pull, it wasn’t enough to choke me or even make it hard to breath, but I could not get up with that holding me down. Fat little fingers pinched at my free wrist, but I fought back with halfhearted waveing and slapping. That hand managed to slip free … so Melson ignored it and starting wrapping wires around my tail. One at the base, one in the center, and one at the tip. I could not even twitch it.

Another thin wire was wrapped, and neatly tied around my chest. Just where was he tying them? I thought the tablet was flat! Two more wires wound themselves around my legs, and soon, with nowhere else to go, my one free hand was captured and restrained. The only movement I could control were my whiskers, and the rise and fall of my chest. A slave would be grateful for that, I was just frustrated I couldn’t break through the wire.

“what is going on here!” I shouted, yelling as best I could without the full range of motion in my neck. Melson ignored me. He placed a hand over my form, a brisk glow flashed over my eyes, and then to my complete and utter shock the tablet I’d been tied to shifted and stretched to match my body. I squeaked, I twitched my whiskers furiously, but I could do nothing to escape. Soon I felt my body sinking into the metal, forming a mold around my spine, tail, and arms.

“Hmm, this one’s tougher than a mouse his size.” Melson said in self reflection. He was studying me. I had no idea how, but he must be getting some sort of information from this. “Better than average strength, impressive agility, flexibility that is simply too much for a mouse”

“Now for the official records." his hands shuffled around the table until he'd procured a sheet of papyrus, a vat of ink, and a quill. "Lets see, mouse, blah blah blah, health, whatevers, yadda yadda … oh this part is annoying. Recommendations on attempts to remove the curse" Melson looked to me, smiled wickedly, and wrote down “Subject Ran Dulac has been returned to normal from a simple remove curse spell, and has begun his journey home.”

It was at that moment I knew … I had no hope for aid from these people.
111111111111111111.title: Melson decides to keep me.

1111111111111111111.content:
That bastard! He went ahead to say my problem was solved, meaning no one would have reason to suspect I was here. He’d get an all new lab specimen to experiment on and I’d spend the rest of my short life in his care. I growled at such a prospect, but I’m not sure how well he heard me. That, in itself, was part of the problem. Even if I could talk just fine, I could not talk loud enough to make much of a difference. There was no way anyone would come down into this hellhole, and even if I was lucky enough for some inspector to notice me I’d be hard pressed to make sure whoever it was knew I wasn’t just a mouse.

Then came the idea that they might not care. I wasn’t from this city, no one knew me and no one has heard of me. Melson just outright assumed I was a lower class citizen and not worth caring about, regardless of actual evidence. Can it be too difficult to believe others would do the same? At the very least, anyone that Melson would work closely with? Other mice and rats might the only company I have for … how long would he keep me alive here?

I narrowed my eyes as his fat little hands came near me, I wasn’t about to discover the limits of his mercy though personal experience, I was going to get out of here. All I needed was a little leeway, and a way to get up the ladder. Melson’s fingers pinched around the metal wires, slowly undoing the three along my tail. I smiled and held still.

This was my chance.

I waited for him to undo the wires around my chest, waited longer for the one around my neck. My right hand hurt as he wasn’t too careful removing that one, and my left was the last one to go … he never got the chance to undo that one, as I curled around, gripped the wire end myself with both my right hand and my teeth, then pulled on it myself. It loosened just enough to slip my tiny little hand through.

“Wha, hey!” Melson screamed, his voice thundering and frightening while his hand shot across to press down on my spine. But I was upright now, and I was curled effectively enough to hold him up. My triangular shaped face pressed hard between the man’s fingers, I shoved through them using my nose like a shovel, and felt the eerie twisting as my body squeezed itself through that small crack in his hand.

It was like slipping a silk dress underneath a doorway, I went through easily and started running. Melson’s other hand slapped down at my current location, but I was amongst bottles and blades and jagged, sharp things. Not only did he fail to hold me secure enough, he managed to cut his hand open and spray some of his blood across the desk.

It smelled just as bad as his skin did, but I smiled as how easily the fool fumbled.

“GodDammit!” the man cursed, cradling his injured hand as I scampered in and around the messy table, putting as much junk and as much distance between us as possible. Thinking ahead on how I hoped to get down off the table, I grabbed a loose metal wire and dragged it along with me. Melson starting picking up, and removing the various things in his way. Mostly delicate bottles that’d be rather expensive to replace. Not to mention whatever contents they held were probably valueable.

I smiled, then started to push one of them off. It was a green bottle, glowing, and with some arid smell that I could not place.

“Noooo!” Melson screamed as it slipped off the table and down to the floor, shattering and splating at the same time. The smell of molten rock soon filled the room, I looked down to see the solid stone floor melting away as whatever that green stuff was ate through it. Melson tried to walk around the table to the side I was on, but he was slow and cautious having to avoid the acid himself. I scampered through the mess until I was once again out of his reach.

But he was fallowing … he could not reach across the table or through all of his equipment to reach me, but he could run around faster than I could run through. If I tried to climb down without distracting him first, I’d never mak- …

“Ouch!” I squeaked myself as I nicked my thigh on one of the sharp blades. It was a surgical scalpel, incredibly sharp, with a long handle providing accuracy. At this size it looked like a decent enough spear. Holding the metal coil in one hand, I drew the scalpel and held it forward like a weapon.

I clambered up a corked bottle, making good use of this body’s wonderful sense of balance, then oriented on Melson. I have to tell you, he looked confused when he saw a mouse wielding a makeshift spear readying itself to fight him. That should have tipped me off that something was wrong, for wasn’t this whole town supposed to be at war with rats?

Mabye the magician simply hadn’t seen it for himself, I doubt he was the sort to charge into battle.

He reached a hand across the table to try and grab me, but I jumped off and ducked out of the way. The bottle toppled over, the cork flew off, and the scent of alcohol soon mixed with smells of death and melting stone. There were too many smells to sort out here, all of them resulting in a horrible combination. Realizing he could not grab quick enough, Melson picked up a small metal tablet, one without any impression in it, and tossed it at me.

Metal slammed against metal in an awful, earsplitting sound, but I ran forward to get out of it’s way and jumped immediately after it landed. With the wire in one hand, the spear in my other, I threw the scalpel point first towards Melson’s right eye.

I smiled as it hit, then flinched as his piercing squeal filled the small chamber. My ears twitched as someone started cheering, but I did not long ponder just who that could be. I used this window of opportunity to tie one end of the wire crudely around some bulky piece of metal, gripped the main length of it with my hand, and repelled down the corner of the table using it’s legs as a brace.

Melson stumbled, falling to his knees as he howled in agony. I could see he’d already pulled the scalpel out by now and was dripping blood all over the floor. This fight suddenly felt like any one of those legendary tales of a single night in armed combat against a massive, terrible dragon. I knew from experience those tales were generally a load of crock.

You need a well trained, specifically armed team of, at the very least, five men to take down a dragon. I’ve done it myself with an army of thirty and some well aimed iron bolts. Any fool who did manage to go one on one with a dragon and win was lucky, not skilled.

If Melson was the dragon in my story, then I knew I needed luck more than I needed anything else.

Luck which, apparently, I didn’t have … the wire was too short to reach the ground.

With blood dripping from his face and an annoying chanting or cheering filling the room, I squeaked out in desparation as the man stumbled towards me. He aimed with his one good eye, and attacked with one hand while the other tried to stop the bleeding, but I just kicked off with my feet to spin around the table’s leg. I shuddered as his hand smashed into the metal, jerked around the table’s contents, and made a few sharp cutting tools clatter to the alcohol soaked floor bellow.

From this angle I could see his alcohol spilling off the edge like an oddly colored waterfall. I looked across at Melson’s furious expression, looked down to the floor bellow me, and jumped … I had half of the table’s height to fall down.

Landing was not pleasant.
1111111111111111111.title: I try to escape.

11111111111111111111.content:
I fell, it seemed slow at first, but that illusion was shattered the moment I neared the floor.

SLAM!

I smashed onto it with my bottom feet first, I felt a sharp sting flow up from my feet and through to my thighs but it faded quickly as I landed onto four feet. Wasting no time I ran forward for no other reason than to put distance between me and Melson, which turned out to be a bright idea as the man swiped and pounded at the ground where I had just been.

I didn’t have much time to ponder the implications but I was impressed by how well I could shrug off that fall. It still hurt, but had lived through the equivalent of falling off a two story building and still be well enough to fight. Just what were the limits?

I was now completely unarmed, the wire left were it was tied. The smells of molten stone were still present but the gaping hole in the middle of the floor was no longer steaming or glowing. Presumably that … whatever it was … acid maybe? Had depleted itself. I was several feet away from Melson before I turned, and he started to stand up.

He was more than just furious.

I could see the alcohol puddle, still growing thanks to that small dripping waterfall, and I could see the now soaked weapons in the center of it. I could try to escape up the stairs, get captured, and end up suffering a worse torment than he’d initially planned.

Or I could go for the surgical cutting instruments and finish the job. He’d have a hard time chasing after me if I chop through his toes.

My ears twitched one more time and then I finally noticed the condition of every caged rat or mouse in the entire room. I could hear them, I could understand them, and by the gods I could sympathize with them. They were all cheering. They all wanted to see me win. A few were offering directions or slinging around encouraging words. One of them, a grey furred mouse that looked a lot like a smaller, lither version of me, was issuing a warning.

“Watch out!” she called in a feminine voice, to which I responded by immediately charging towards the nearest wall.

My back feet lifted off the ground in a comical fashion as an explosive and concussive force hit me indirectly from behind. I turned to see a burning scorch mark in the stone at my previous location, not quite as damaging to the floor as that acid had been but more than lethal if it connects with something like me. I spied Melson raising his arms and making obscene gestures as he prepared to cast again.

His hand lit up in indication of power, he thrust his palm towards me … and cursed rather loudly as I dodged him yet again. The explosion cracking the glass of one of the bottom cages, to which the large brown rat inside ruthlessly exploited by smashing his shoulders against the weak point.

I was disappointed to see the glass hold, but I was too busy dodging a second scorching ray to go help him. I could have kept up the false target charade if he’d fought like a clichÃ©d caster, standing still while blasting smoothly and predictably. I could have stood in front of one cage after another and let him weaken them for me, then eventually they’d break and I’d have some backup in this fight. Surely nothing in this room held an allegiance to that man.

But Noooo, none of the people I fight could ever settle for being predicable, he had this crazy idea of fallowing me on foot to make sure of his next shot!

This was my turn to curse … I ran right between his legs, squeaked and zagged as a sudden stomp threatened to end my life, then shot underneath the table.

A scorching ray exploded behind my tail, lifting my hind legs off the ground and sending me head over heels across the floor. I rolled and sprawled, gathering a number of small bruises along with minor burn marks on my feet and tail, but no time to worry about them as Melson ducked down to aim his fire attack directly at me.

How many more times could he cast it? I heard his spell pool was supposed to be limited, so surely he could not cast indefinitely. Not that he wasn’t big enough to win a fight with his fists if he got close enough. Assuming the glow in his hands meant he could cast well enough, I shot across the floor, circling around the acid hole, and fell head over heals a second time as that ray exploded at my back.

This time my fur singed, my tail was actually burnt, and the concussive force made me dizzy. But I had the added advantage of falling into alcohol. A quick lick of which eased some of my pain, while it aided the majority of my cuts. I could feel it splashing up around me, soaking into my fur, mixing with what little blood still dripped from my wounds.

Then I realized alcohol was flammable, and my opponent was shooting flames out of his hands.

There were five weapons to choose from, one was another scalpel like the one I’d just thrown. If I could stab out both Melson’s eyes I’d be a hero among these mice. But otherwise it was too bulky to use. There was a giant saw shaped tool that I might be able to throw if I could spin it, but it was just too big to use effectively. There was an alcohol soaked ninja star with a hole in the center, I could use that like a shield and a cutting tool if need be … which was odd, because I saw no reason for Melson to have one.

There was a small screwdriver, like, seriously small. Small enough for me to use. But that wasn’t exactly a weapon. The last object was a strait blade, longer than my tail but thin enough to wield as an oddly shaped sword. The handle was understandably large, but the blade was single edged.

Logically, I’d want to grab that screwdriver regardless of what weapon I use, but my choices of a weapon were between that cutting tool and what looked like a ninja star. To hell with figuring out why he’d use one.

Looking back, I saw Melson’s hands glowing again, I saw the rage and furry in his eyes as he prepared to cast … I had only a few seconds to choose then get out of this alcohol.
11111111111111111111.title: I ran for the blades.

choices: I awoke to an empty room.
I awoke to a room filled with rats.
111111111111111111111.content:
My jaws opened and closed around that tiny screwdriver in a flash whilst my paws gripped hard onto the wooden handle of that metal blade. It was awkwardly large for me, something akin to a greatsword of bastard sword. Not bothering with stance or form, I let the thing splash and drag behind me as I dashed out of the foul smelling puddle. My tail and whiskers flailing with droplets of alcohol spilling everywhere. There was a suggestion of sparks as the metal blade scraped against stone at a decent speed.

I made a hard and sudden turn to my left, away from the stairway and towards the nearest shelf. Not one of the many with glass rodent cages but rather one filled with tomes, bottles, instruments. Things that were surely expensive and difficult to replace. I saw the shadows in front of me dance around, reacting to the light given off by some arcane spell far behind me. I dove into the air and flipped, curling into a tight ball so only my back and tail were exposed, protecting my vulnerable face.

Pain exploded around me as yet another lance of flame ignited on the floor bellow me. The concussive force tossed me higher and further than I could jump, tossing me hard into the random, multicolored beakers and bottles I was running towards. Tightening my teeth around the screwdriver I uncurled, held a tight grip on that “sword” and slunk behind the liquids and paper lining the far wall. I noticed the hair on my right flank was alight with a small blaze and quickly snuffed it out with my paw.

“Godamn you, foul rodent! Are you a curse in and of yourself!?” The fat mage shouted while crawling out from under the desk. He examined the blood dripping out of his damaged eye and soaking into his robes. Carefully unfolding from within the relative safety of the shelf, I could see him look through his one good eye and take in jut how much damage he’d taken. The sound of anguish and disgust mixed with a healthy dose of anger and vengeance was something I was used to hearing. It had finally sunk in how this battle would cost him.

But I had my own injuries and exhaustion to worry about. Breathing rapidly, my heart beating at a furious pace, and my feet stinging from so much running and falling, I had enough in me for perhaps one more run before I collapsed. My tail still stung with that dull throb, I was hot and tired and smelled like so many awful things at once. I carefully slunk onto four legs and slipped farther towards the back. Putting more stuff between me and mister flubby pants.

“W-wwaaugh” the man wailed, perhaps on the verge of crying.

Working to calm myself and get my breathing under control, I stood up to two legs and gripped that weapon I’d chosen experimentally. I held it out as if it were any other blade, then swung it slowly to the right and left. The weight was rather awkward, but there were a number of reasons ranging from the type of metal, the fact my hands were new, and just the shape of the handle behind that. I was thankful I could hold the thing at all, or that I hadn’t made an egregious error when choosing this tool over another one.

I huffed one last time and closed my eyes in response to that tingle of fear flowing down my spine, only ending at the tip of my tail.

‘This sword isn’t much, but it will have to do.’ I thought to myself, lips pressed around the screwdriver in my mouth. While I wouldn’t be able to do fancy tricks with it any time soon, to compensate for the alien strangeness of both the body and weapon the actual blade was ridiculously sharp. This wasn’t a weapon so much as a surgical tool, and as such it’s thin edge was designed to slice through flesh with ease. Well, specifically mouse flesh …

Was human skin a great deal tougher than a rodent’s?

With a shiver making my knees twitch, I assumed as close to a formal stance as possible with these humorously wide hips. My knees bent, toes splayed, and tail painfully erect, I tapped one of the nearby bottles to produce a soft clink.

Clink! Clink! Clink!

And then immediately scurried off to the left, avoiding contact with anything but the bottom of the shelf. Through small gaps and distorted images from the occasional half full bottle I saw Melson stagger his way towards the shelf in an angry huff. He furiously pulled ingredients and potions away from where I had lead him too, and appeared all the angrier once he realized I wasn’t there.

“DO YOU THINK YOU CAN TOY WITH ME?!” his thunderous voice echoed in my skull, yet another pain for me to ignore as I silently scaled an especially tall bottle with some orange liquid inside. “I WILL GUT YOU LIKE A FISH AND TURN YOU INTO A HANDBAG!”

The man’s fists started to glow with arcane magic, his lips were already in the motion to cast another spell. Did the man intend to blow up the entire shelf and everything on it just to get rid of a mouse? I wasn’t too keen on figuring out how far he’d go as with but a light kick I was already diving through the air towards his arm. My left hand gripped the cloth along his elbow, my right hand dug the sword deep into his joint. I was honestly surprised by how cleanly it went in, right between the two largest bones and stabbing through the cartilage. I could see the tip protruding from the other side of his arm.

And I could see his rage transform quite utterly into horror as paralysis afflicted his right arm and his hard learned magics faded away. The man seemed too stunned to move. Or perhaps he was just having trouble seeing me with his one eye. An easy thing to fix, I suppose. Pulling the blade out carefully, I gripped cloth with my two feet and my free hand then started to climb. That sure got his attention. He made an odd moaning sound, like a dog sick with a stomach flu, and began to flail about in an effort to get me off. He couldn’t move the hand I’d stabbed so it was rather easy to climb. Didn’t even have to worry about blood making it slippery, for it trailed down the length of his arm. His other hand seemed torn between keeping his eye from bleeding out, addressing this new wound, and staying the hell away from that surgical tool lest it end up useless as well.

By the time I was at his shoulders I stated quite boldly “I wonder how big a handbag you’d make” a few inches from his ear. Not up to calling my bluff, though perhaps not smart enough to surrender, or perhaps pass out from blood loss, he swiped at me with his one usable arm. I lay flat on my stomach, letting the palm of his hand crush my soft, squishy body into his shoulder, then I shot forward. His fingers easy to slip out of, the pressing weight that seemed to jam my ribs into my spine didn’t seem to have any lasting effect, and I was right up in his blood covered face.

His good eye disappeared under an ever-growing puddle of red in the first swipe, so in retrospect it might have been overkill to continue stabbing and tearing. Pushing the sword in as far as it would go and twisting it around ruthlessly. I stopped soon enough, but that was because I had to.

His weight shifted upon his death, and his body fell over backwards with a wet crunch. In the weightlessness of freefall my tail spun around wildly but my arms and legs seemed to instantly brace themselves for that inevitable collision into a pool of red.

SPLAT!

My fur soaked and that awful smell swiftly getting worse, I dragged myself towards the man’s brutalized skull and pulled my blade out of it. Holding it high for all to see, I could not help but look across the room at the rows upon rows of rodents in glass cages, eagerly looking down to see what I do next. Awkward or not, I could get used to this scalpel-esc tool, it had more than proven it’s worth.

But now I was tired, the blood was more than uncomfortable, and I just knew I’d pass out and sleep at some point soon. Looking towards the nearest cage on the lowest point, I clambered down off Melson's corpse and took off running. It was slow at first, a soft pitter-patter that splashed through blood and left sloshy stains on the hard floor, but I soon picked up speed for the charge. Hilt of my sword held high, as soon as I was close enough I slammed it hard into the glass with all my might, forming a healthy crack on the wall. I was exhausted, but it wasn't enough ... so I picked the sword up and smashed again. Then again. My arms straining to move at all, I twisted my grip and stabbed the edge through with a last ditch effort ... then fell asleep on the spot.
111111111111111111111.title: I pick the "sword".

choices: We both escape into the city.
Melson ... comes back from the dead?
11111111111111111112.content:
I slammed to the floor, cringed as my front paws buckled under my own weight, and glanced behind me while trying to regain posture. Landing hurt. I could survive that sort of fall, apparently, but it hurt to move, it hurt to breath, it hurt to …

It was about to hurt worse, I could see Melson’s bloodstained hands were glowing. He had the hand with a cut pressed against his bleeding eye, and it fell down his cheeks and onto his shirt. Meanwhile his free hand took on an eerie red glow, oriented towards me, and flexed.

I didn’t waste any time diving behind the table leg, letting it shield me for a second time as heat and flame roared past. I had to curl my tail around my knees to keep it from getting burned, my ears went wide and spread far away from my head. An attempt at cooling maybe? Somehow my ears got warmer and the rest of me felt cooler, even though the heat should have been completely unbearable. When the flame stopped, I tore out from underneath the table immediately.

When I was a good two feet away I turned back in time to see Melson ducking under it, then cursing as I wasn’t there anymore. He aimed for me with his good hand, I tried to swerve to the far right and prop up against the glass outer walls of the nearest cage, but the man was in an awkward position without any hands to prop him up. He quickly toppled over and the scorching ray shot out from his fingertips to smash into a glass cage a few feet off the ground.

Blinking, I looked up to see the shattered glass, still holding but now significantly weaker, and a tiny, grey mouse backing away from the superheated material. The scorching ray spell dealt damage with the blunt force trauma involved with the explosion as well as heat damage. It didn’t generally melt or catch things on fire, not that it was incapable of either. The tiny little mouse inside, smaller than me even, ruthlessly pounded her tiny little fists into the biggest crack. She was exploiting this sudden weakness for all it was worth.

Looking back to Melson, I saw him struggling to get up, struggling to stay alert despite his blood loss. He was now mixed with alcohol and his own dark red, gushing, iron scented blood. The mixture of so many smells, from scorching and melting stone, to ridiculously strong acids, the scents of death, decay, rat feces, sweat, fear, strong drinks … there was just too much to sort through. The only thing I could do with my sense of smell was try to ignore it before my eyes could water.

My shoulder wasn’t hurting as much as when I’d landed, and I needed that. I took off running for the doorway as Melson aimed his free hand towards me. His head was just barely above the puddle of alcohol and acid formed hole, if he were to fall over again he’d land in all of the sharp pointy objects he’d knocked over earlier. Trying to make sure of his shot as best he could from a horrid angle, the blood from his bad eye would actually dribble down his face to make things difficult for his good eye. I could only imagine what was going through his mind as he suffered such.

But, his hands and clothing soaked in alcohol, his fingers glowing in preparation to cast, I could only stand there and smile.

As the man burst into flames.

Fire shot out from his fingers as per usual, but rather than blast forward towards the target it ignited, and exploded, directly onto the robes around his hand. He started to scream, and I put my hands over my ears. It didn’t help much but by the gods could this man scream! Sure, he had enough … eeek!

I squeaked, growing squeamish myself as the flame danced across his clothing and burst across the puddle, Melson lost his balance while trashing and squirming uselessly in the overwhelming heat … and fell over backwards into the spikes and scalpels and other sharp things. This prompted him to squirm around even more, but that only pushed them in farther. Tearing through his swiftly disintegrating cloths and spilling even more blood onto the floor. His skin blackened, turning crispy.

As horrible a fate as this was, made even worse by the fact he wasn’t dead yet, I was pleased with how easy the fight turned out. I scampered around the flaming puddles and the screaming, writhing mage. I glanced up to the other mice and rats still locked in their cages … then I considered if I should try to free them or not. Physically, doing so would be a challenge. The only one I might be able to get out was the female mouse and … oh! She was still pounding on the cage. She looked tired, the glass itself looked about ready to crumble.

Everyone else? I’d need to find the keys. And then I’d need to be able to get the keys over here. Then I’d need to be able to use the keys. Unless I found an easy way to do it quickly and quietly, getting everyone out before anyone else came down here, THEN somehow making it outside the city without getting captured again. I didn’t actually owe these rodents anything. As cowardly as it may seem, I could very easily just escape on my own. I’m not sure what I’d do afterward, but …

But no. If any of these rodents had suffered as much as I think they did, as much as it looks like they did, then it was my duty to get them out. If Melson died right here and now, a fool who lit himself on fire trying to shoot flames at a mouse, then no one would feed, water, or clean the cages. Everyone here would likely starve to death before any other human enters this building. I know I would have tried to stay as far away from that mage as I could, what if everyone else here felt the same?

There was a cracking sound. I was standing right at the base of the stairs when that female mouse managed to break apart a small chunk of glass, just small enough for her to squeeze through. You know … if didn’t have a problem with loosing weight the easy way. I was about to call something out to her when …

WOOOSH! BOOOM!

The fire trailed up the alcohol, snaked it’s way over the top of the table, and heated all of the bottles that were stored up there. One of them exploded with a firey, twirling ball of sparkles that danced around the room in ever widening circles before crashing into yet another glass cage. This one smashed open in a shower of fine glass, leaving the three rats inside … ouch.

One of them was cut badly and could barely walk, another seemed fine, having been shielded by his companions, the third … was dead. A large pane of glass had sliced his head off.

Looking towards the table I saw another explosion shoot out from some flaming bottle, this time a blue shower of energy trailed out in all directions, smashing into the roof, the walls, and the floor with a shower of green sparks. All the mice in the area were cowering as far away from the cage walls as they could, save the two rats and the grey mouse who’d managed to free themselves.

Sort of. They still needed to get down.

Another explosion, fallowed by two others, went strait into the roof and caused an ear shattering, earsplitting crash. I could see dust and a few stones break loose and rain down into the basement as the floor above us weakened. Another bottle started shaking, popped like corn, and spread a gooey red liquid across the room in quant little splashes. I dodged it, not sure what the stuff did.

This place was quickly turning into a deathtrap. And … by the gods! There were more bottles over on another shelf? I covered my ears as explosion after explosion rocketed through the room. Realizing just how ridiculously dangerous this was, I hopped up the first stair and then hopped up the other step. I wanted out of here, nothing I could do to protect the other mice, just had to hope the rest of them lived long enough to escape. This place was pure chaos!

I hopped step after step, trying to ignore the carnage, the screams, the smoke rising to the roof as the fire continued to burn with all the fuel Melson’s fat body provided it. Once I’d gotten to the door at the top … I realized I had no way to open it. No way to slip through, the crack under the door was only as wide as my head, my shoulders and hips could have never fit. The room was harder and harder to see into, it was just black smoke occasionally brightened by puffs of sparkling magic and the dull orange glow of a steadily burning flame. I coughed a little. The smoke must have been getting to me. Then blinked as a grey, fuzzy fluff ball hopped up the steps towards me. That same female mouse? I blinked as she cleared the step to reach me, gave me a brief hug, then shot towards the door.

“ThankYouSirNowComeOnWeHaveToGetOutOfHere!” she shouted in panicked, rapid, but otherwise normal feminine voice.

“We can’t, we need the key!” I shouted at the top of my lungs, mostly making sure she could hear me over the explosions.

“What? No we don’t, there’s a hole right here! Now come on!” she screamed back, grabbing my paw and shoving her head through the crack.

“Wha …” I almost fainted with surprise as her chest collapsed in on itself and she squeezed her lithe form through with ease. Still pulling on my hand, I was then forced to do the same.
11111111111111111112.title: I ran for the stairs.

1111111111111111112.content:
“I can’t believe their’s actually another one like her.” Melson would continue, looking off to another cage. I was slightly relieved that his gaze was no longer on me, but the fact he’d just wrote a ‘report’ saying I was all fine and dandy I wasn’t in the mood to feel good about anything. My name wasn’t even Dulac! It was Xander! The fat little bastard didn’t bother to ask. Not that I really expected him to care, in light of recent developments.

“Five fingers on one each front paw, and a sturdy heal on each back leg.” he looked back to me with an insatiable lust for knowledge. “I wonder if you two are related by chance. Haha, an entire family turned into mice against their will? A fool who got a little too used to his new body and decided to fool around with the lady mice? Yes, you’ll be an excellent specimen to study.”

I was quietly twitching my whiskers as I listened. Another mouse … with five fingers instead of the usual four? Could there really be another human trapped in this awful place? Oh gods, if so then for how long? I’d have to find her and rescue her … I’d have to rescue every rodent in this tiny piece of hell, if I ever got the chance. All I needed was to wait for the wires to slip off, wait for some way to move around, then I could slip up the stairs and through the …

No, those stairs were pretty hard to climb. I could manage, probably, but not quickly, quietly, or easily. And that door would be a serious obstacle if I can’t figure out a way to open it. I could probably fight Melson head on and … no … no that would just be stupid. This guy knows magic, he’s bound to have at least a low power offensive spell. Given his profession it’s probably some form of paralysis or restraining magic. Not to mention all of his equipment, some of which is bound to be enchanted.

Like this tablet.

Melson sighed as well, putting his paper away somewhere I could not see, then cupping his hand over me. I saw nothing but fat fingers, then nothing but a blue glow as it enveloped my face … then I felt something warm and wet creeping up over my shoulders. I blinked, tried to look down, then gasped. It wasn’t the wire keeping my held in place, it was the metal itself slowly molding around my shoulders, my cheeks, my ears. I tried to squirm, but of course that did nothing. I was already held immobile while this metal liquefied and oozed around me.

My tail sunk in, fallowed by arms, my legs, and my hips. My belly and face were still sticking out for a while, which I took full advantage of by breathing in as much as possible whilst air was cut off from everywhere else. My fur seemed to clump together, I could feel my own sweat build up as it now had nowhere to go, and the entire thing was warm. Very warm. Not scaling hot, but warm enough to be uncomfortable. Stupid laws of thermodynamics.

I stared up at the ceiling … or rather that single bright lamp that made seeing the actual roof impossible. My eyes were pleading, my mouth wasn’t able to move anymore, I just sucked in air through my nose and twitching my top two whiskers. It felt extremely unsettling to note that some of my facial whiskers were trapped in the metal tablet.

Then the entire thing closed around my face.

I would have screamed if I were able, the air was suddenly cut off completely, it was darker than even a moonless night, it was stiff and muggy and hot with only the scent of my own sweat to fill my senses.

I heard Melson giggling. This was the moment I swore, to myself, that I would figure out a way to kill that bastard even if I had to be a ghost to do it. I could feel the tablet lifting up, then moving, before sweet, sweet air pushed through a parting metal seal. No light came through, so the metal was still molded around my face, but with my nose sticking out I could breath clean … ok, I could breath air, no matter how distasteful it’s content, and smell something other than myself.

I heard something sliding open. I heard something squeak, probably another mouse, fallowed by a beautiful sounding feminine voice.

“Let him go you big s-stupid … stupid HUMAN!” shouting out that last word as if it were a curse. Her voice was pleasing for three reasons, the first being that it sounded … well … normal. It wasn’t loud and thundering, or eerily quiet. She spoke out, which made her sound different than that interrogator who was being deliberately quiet. The second reason was that she hated Melson, meaning that at least for the moment no sort of mind control was going on. No matter how bad the prison is, so long as I can think of an escape and hope for an escape, there is a chance I’ll escape. If I’m somehow convinced that I like imprisonment, getting out is never going to happen.

The third reason I found her voice charming, was that it was a ‘voice’ … I wasn’t going to be alone with my thoughts, I’d be talking to other mice. Salving off boredom and terror alike with conversation and emotional support. There were more than one rodent in each of the cages, so even if I couldn’t see anything I was fairly certain I’d be placed in a cage with someone else.

Someone with whom I could actually talk to. Without screaming at the top of my lungs. But whilst I was taking keen notes on every aspect of that single spoken sentence, Melson was ignoring her entirely. He probably couldn’t hear her speaking, even if she was speaking actual Umea or it was somehow magically translated for him.

I heard a metallic ‘click’ as the tablet dropped into something hard, then stretched out my injured, bleeding tail as the metal seemed to slide off of it. It vanished from my legs, my waist, my shoulders … I held my hands up to my neck and tried pulling at the stuff as my head was the last to go. Gasping for breath, so delighted to be able to take an entire lungful and breath in through my mouth, I collapsed to the floor. I took note of a tiny little gray mouse sitting in the corner, then tried to look up at the top of the cage.

My head wouldn’t work, so I immediately went for the next best thing and rolled over. Laying on my back, I could see Melson’s hand glowing with a soft blue while shifting, liquid metal floated just underneath his palm. I twitched visibly as he pushed on the glass wall to my left and the entire room began to shift and slide to the right. This wasn’t a cage, it was a glass shelf!

Lazily looking to the left, then to the right, then back to the roof hosting a strange glow from a tiny little lantern … I realized it was a very good way to hold something in place. This thing would be difficult to escape from, and that’s even without taking unknown magical wards into consideration. I groaned, glancing back towards the open glass ‘wall’ that showed out into the actual room. Melson was no longer watching me, nor my cellmate, he was over at the desk looking through papers and bottles.

I glanced to the other walls and saw that these weren’t clear, either they weren’t glass at all or someone had painted over them. While trying to sit up I wondered if they might be enchanted to dull and clear at Melson’s word. But at least they weren’t one way. It would have been an even more intimidating prison if Melson could see inside, but it was too heavily tinted for us to see out. I was just busy thanking whoever birthed that monster for just how inexperienced he was at the prison warden business … if this qualified … when soft, gentle hands forced me to lay back down.

“Don’t sit up, you need your rest sir. You’ve lost a lot of blood and … and this must be a hard day for you. Just don’t, I’ll … I’ll try to treat your wound.”

I blinked, struggling for a moment before realizing I didn’t have the energy. Not being able to breath readily will do that to you. “Thank you mis. My name … is …” it was much harder to talk then I thought it’d be. More draining. She scurried over to my tail, poked it a bit, then pressed her hands around the bleeding area and started to tighten hard … there wasn’t any cloth to wrap around it, so she just kept holding it. Painfully so. Until the last bit of bleeding stopped and all that could seep out was droplets of plasma.

It didn’t actually take long, but it was enough time for me to get my energy back.

“My name is Xander. What’s yours kind mis?” I asked.

She turned and smiled, weird seeing a smile on the face of what was clearly a mouse. But even her eyes looked expressive.

“My name’s Maori. Anything I can do to help, so long as you return the favor once I hatch an escape plan.”

“Escape … yes, we have to escape.” I nodded in agreement.

“And kill that …”
“And kill that …”

We were both talking in union while glaring towards the fat little wizard mumbling at his desk. We stopped looking at him and started looking at each other … I noticed her five fingers, one too many for a normal mouse. Interesting how many things we had in common.

“If your escape attempt involves putting a nail through his ear, I’m all for it.”

Maori smiled.

11111111111111111121.content:
“So you want Melson dead too huh?” Maori giggled. “That sure didn’t take long. How’d he manage to catch you?”

I started to sit up, propping my arms under my spine and leaning my chest forward. At the moment I was looking at Moari’s face from between my legs, and she was looking at me from … lets say, an interesting angle. But her attention was thankfully focused on my tail and on my answer.

“I …”

She was apparently too focused, for she interrupted me the moment I started to talk.

“I bet it was the trap cages wasn’t it, they stick giant rectangle traps inside mouse holes so that they snap shut right as your running to safety. That’s how they got me, one of those monsters chased me inside the wall …” her face twisted into a mixture of anger and sorrow. “Then it … then the thing laughed as it caught me.”

The fact she kept calling humans ‘monster’ or ‘it’ was concerning, but I decided to shrug it off. This poor girl had been through a lot.

“Actually I was just walking into the street when some passing lady stepped on my tail. She sc- …”

But she cut me off again. “Walking into the street!?” her voice filled with shock and outrage. “How in the nine Litter Boxes did you end up in the streets?”

I blinked at the rather colorful language. Nine … litter boxes? Well, I guess that’s a close enough parallel to hell. From a mouse’s perspective. Answering the question “I was trying to find someone who could give me a ma- …” but she interrupted me again.

“Find someone? You mean another mouse? There’s a mapmaker in this city?” she seemed excited.

“Well, no … I mean I would have if I could find one, but I was searching for a human mapmaker. Anyone who could give me directions.”

Maori leapt back in complete and utter surprise. “You were actually looking for a human?! Why? What could you possibly be thinking!”

“I can talk can’t I? I can still speak Umea even with these new vocal cords, and most people you meet are actually nice. At least the one that caught me di- …”

“Nice?” she screamed, shaking her head in disbelief. “Where the heck have you been? There’s no such thing as a nice human.”

“There are plenty. The guy who captured me comes to mind. I wish he could see what was going on here.”

“You were captured by a human and your sitting here telling me, with a completely strait face, that it was a nice one? What did you somehow fail sarcasm school or were you trying to be serious?”

“There’s more to it than that, I did happen to give myself up. You jus- …”

“What?! Are you mental? You actually wanted to come here? Oh of all the …”

I interrupted her this time. “You just never let me finish a sentence.”

Maori turned her back to me and slumped. “Sure I have, but every sentence out of your mouth is horrible and stupid. Mostly stupid.”

I slapped a paw to my face, having difficulty accepting what I was hearing. “Can you at least let me finish?”

Her ears perked, the mouse sighed … then she finally turned around and nodded. “Might as well. Not much else to do while trapped here.”

“Alright, now first off I’m a royal guard.”

She blinked, starting to interrupt me. “You know the king? And your not afraid of Giantkind? Are you from the Infernal Depths.” she actually smiled, her face brightening a bit … before me shaking my head brought her euphoria back down.

“No, I’m from Iron Wall. Never heard of that place.”

“Iron … hey wait, that’s a human kingdom, lead by …” she started to piece things together.

“I am Xander, bound to serve Lord Reginald Finny. It was during my duties when a magic wielding assassin broke into the castle … or maybe he teleported, I didn’t actually see him come in … he tore through other guards and just left them on the floor, but I guess I pissed him off. He cast something at me, and for the past two nights I have been living in the rather disorienting position of a mouse.”

She backed away, the female looked … horrified actually. I wasn’t sure how to handle this sort of reaction, but knew that stepping closer would have been a bad idea. “S-so … you’re a … you’re a …”

“A human?” I finished, nodding. Then I held my right hand up for emphasis. “Five fingers and all. Guess some aspects still shine through even the toughest magic.”

“A … human.” She almost choked on the words. It was something of an insult for me, were we really that bad? I can’t picture the last time I saw anyone back home mistreat any animal. Hmm … but then Iron Wall had these little magic charms that kept small critters out of the food supply, so we didn’t have to kill any. It got me thinking just how different the dynamic is when each side is fighting for the same food, and each needs it just as desperately as the other. Then of course, there was Melson. Who by all counts of decency should be tried as a criminal.

“Yes, I’m a human … or I was … the lady who stepped on me screamed, one thing lead to another which lead to a group of city guards hearing me speak. I let myself be captured because I figured that was easier than resisting, then after a short interrogation I was sent here.” I paused a bit, tilting my head. “I am not that gross. I bathe once every month, I keep clean.”

Moari was pressed against the wall, trying to stay as far away from me as possible. “Only once a month!?” somehow, this outraged even more than Melson had. “EwEwEwEwewewewewew!” she closed her eyes, shook her wrists frantically, and tried to wipe them off on the glass. “I can’t believe I actually touched one! Gah! And there’s even slime on my hands! Ewwww! GetitoffGetitoffGetitoff!”

“That’s blood, not slime! You were touching an open wound!” shaking my head at her showy display of distaste, I decided to interject. “We aren’t all as creepy or vile as that Melson guy I’ll have you know.”

“Ewwww … J-just stay um … over there. Waaaaay over there.” she pointed to the far corner of the cage.

Sighing, I obliged. “Well I guess this answers one of my next questions.”

“W-what question … no! Don’t turn around, just … just sit there.”

“Well, Melson seemed interested in the fact I had five fingers. That’s not supposed to be normal for mice is it?”

“N-no …” I turned around to look at her, and she seemed downcast. “I was always considered weird as a child, because of that, but there are worse mutations. Six feet being the prime example. Or giant bat wings. Or being born without fur.”

Smirking some at the mental image of a naked mouse. “The fat idiot put me and you in the same cage because we both have five fingers.”

“Why? It’s not that special is it?”

“I’m pretty sure my hands are weird because I’m a transformed human, not a natural born mouse. I just figured, as I’m sure Melson has …” I stalled.

“What? You figured what?” Maori leaned forward, eager to hear what I had to say. She didn’t object to the fact I was looking at her, from this distance at least, so I kept staring.

“I figured I’d ask if you used to be a human as well. Even as a child or something, but I guess that’s stu- …”

“Stupid!” she shouted. She tried to say something else, but it devolved in incomprehensible ramblings for the most part. The few words I could make out “B-but … no, that’s just stupid, completely stupid … I …” then she got her rage back. “I am a MOUSE! And don’t you EVER forget that you fucking HUMAN! You stay on your side of the cage, I’ll stay on mine, and lets make every effort to keep your air from touching my air.”

With that she turned in a circle and slumped into her little corner. I stuck my tiny, triangular shaped nose into my own little corner and curled up as tight as I could. It was surprisingly tight, and surprisingly cozy. This new spine just seemed to bend the right way for sleeping in cramped spaces on a flat floor. At least compared to my old body.

“My apologies for disturbing you M-mis …”I almost said ‘maori’ but figured ‘mis’ would be less personsl and thus less likely to make her lash out. “I shall do my best to keep my presence from making you ill. I didn’t know I was that disgusting.” then with that, I was quiet.

She was quiet.

Even Melson and the other rats were quiet.

There wasn’t any food around, no beds, no water to drink. It wasn’t even dark enough to actually fall asleep. Great if you plan to stay up or want to feel welcomed, but when you don’t have anything to do or anyone to talk to the light just gets annoying.
11111111111111111121.title: I asked if she used to be human.
