11111111111111111122.content:
“You and a dozen others, at least by the looks of things. I haven’t had a chance to talk with anyone sense that monster trapped me in here. No one else ever goes into my cage … I’m glad I finally have a cellmate. It’s an awful feeling, being so lonely for so long.”

“How long were you in here?” I asked, both worried and concerned. If she was here for very long it meant my chances of escape were low. Likewise, if she was here for very long it meant she had been suffering for that entire length of time. Practicality meets empathy, and the meeting went well.

“I’ve been here for about a week or two. Too long, far too long, I’m supposed to be looking for the … well.”

I cocked an eyebrow, slowly sitting so I could nurse my tail’s open wound and sit on my hind legs for once. “Looking for what?”

“You’ll probably think it’s silly, but I was looking for the Infernal Depth. I found this old map that states it’s somewhere on an Island to the east, buried in a volcano, and surrounded by giant mouse-eaters.”

Blinking at the description, all I could tell was that it was well defended. Unless the ‘giant mouse eaters’ were just normal sized things that happened to eat mice. “That place sounds … dangerous. So it’s what, a vault or something?”

“No! It’s a kingdom, the Dragon-riders and the giants made some alliance with the Armor king generations ago.”

“I think your going to have to start over from the beginning, I haven’t heard of any of this.”

Maori sighed deeply, glanced towards the grumbling Melson, then nodded. “Probably should. I am Maori Whiteborn. Orphan child thanks to a vicious feline, and tactical scout to the Green Wall Kingdom.”

“Green Wall? Wasn’t that place destroyed a few decades ago?” my brow furrowed in confusion.

“Well of course, how else would mice be able to take control of it? If there were still humans living there we’d hardly want the place. But please don’t interrupt if you want to hear the end of this.”

I repeated the words ‘if there were still humans’ in my head over and over before nodding. “My apologies mis.”

“Call me Maori.” she winked before continuing. “Anyway, about a month ago this army of Blood Rats calling itself the ‘rat army’ … stupid name in my opinion, it’s too cliché, declared our lands were under their control, and that we’d have to surrender and submit to their slavery if we had any hope of survival …” she blinked, showing the same concern and sadness she’d had when I first saw her. “Those were trying times. We lost many good soldiers trying to defend against them, but th- …” she was now gasping at the words.

“You don’t have to tell me right now, I’d u-understand.”

“No! It’s not that it’s just … w-we … their sacrifices gave us enough time to close down the walls and seal all the cracks. They even kept most of the engineers alive so we could repair any damage their rock slingers and heavy bruisers did to the wall. But it’s siege warfare now, it’s not a matter of who wins or not, it’s a matter of who can hold out the longest. From what we’ve seen, and that even some of the Dragonriders are having trouble with them at their home, our little castle isn’t even taking up their full attention. Meanwhile we are scrambling to get by.”

Thinking it over, it sounded like her people were up against superior numbers rather than superior forces. If they didn’t have heavy artillery … wait, what was I thinking? What ‘artillery’ can a rat create that would break through human masonry? But I shook off such thoughts, better not to seem condescending. “So you don’t think you can win.”

“Not on our own no, not if they can keep us pinned down without the slightest effort. But if we give them the castle, they’d just get even stronger! So we hold out to the last breath. I was … I was sent as a desperation effort, me and … me and five others … snuck past the army and were sent to find the Infernal Depths to seek aid from the Armor king who rules there. Only … only me and two others actually made it into the forest alive. We all had to split up to throw the army off our trail, and … and …” a tear rolled down her nose and splashed onto the white floor.

I reached an arm out and tried to hug her, which she gratefully accepted. “I’ll do what I can to help Maori, this I swear.”

“I’m supposed to be strong, but if I can’t get out of this human city and find the Armor king, then all of their deaths will be meaningless. I j-just … I can’t accept that.”

“Indeed, the first step is to get out of here. Away from that creep Melson, perhaps get to Ronald and tell him what’s going on in here.”

Maori perked her ears up into my chin, still on the brink of sobbing but restraining the actual tears. “Wh-who … who’s Ronald?”

“A human I spoke with. If he saw what was going on in this room, and what Melson was lying about on paper, I bet we’d be out of here in no time.”

“You … wait, you can speak with humans?”

“Well yeah, I uh …” I started to explain, but gulped when she cut me off.

“That’s, ugh! That’s disgusting. How could you ever stand staying close to one long enough to learn? How did you keep your eardrums from exploding?”

Figuring this wasn’t the best time to mention that I wasn’t really a mouse, I went with a half lie. “It’s part of some … magic, thing … yeah. And hey, it will come in handy later on, trust me.”

“I mean, I know I can understand humans, and that’s not supposed to be normal … but for a mouse who isn’t training with the Armor king to actually speak to them? That’s just … that’s just ludicrous.”

“Well bathe me in butter and call me ludicrous, because I’m not giving up my only advantage.”

“Bathe you in …” she seemed stunned for a moment, then hugged me tighter while bursting into giggles. “I’m s-sorry for making fun of you, I’m not trying to honest, I just haven’t had someone to talk to in so long.”

“It’s fine Maori, I understand completely. I wouldn’t want to spend this much time with Melson either.” I glared through the glass cage, then blinked as the fat man got up and started climbing the stairs. He was too far away for me to hear anything but I could see him stomping his way up and shoving through the door.

“I just have to save the king, I can’t let everyone down.”

“That’s another thing I understand completely.” considering how badly my luck went with my rescue attempt, it would be karmic fate Maori was somehow permanently transformed into a human while I spent my days as a mouse. Heck, all Melson would have to do is have a change of heart, try to turn me back, and get which mouse is which a little mixed up. It could happen!

Moari looked up at me and asked. “Just what has you so worried? You thinking of an escape plan already?”

Smirking I sat down to four legs so I could see her eye to eye. I was taller while sitting up, but like this our heads were at roughly the same level. Only my spine and rump actually looked big enough to distinguish us too, as hers were unusually slender.

“Actually I was hoping to clarify a few things …”
11111111111111111122.title: I asked how she got here.

111111111111111112.content:
“So, wait, you mean you can’t remove this curse then? We have to hire a someone else?” Ronald asked, trying to take everything in. I was too busy trying to stay conscious to pipe in with my own concerns.

“Hohohoh! You’d have to get a completely different caliber of magician, boy. I’m talking someone with the power to summon meteor storms, enough magic to decimate an entire kingdom! Whoever cast this spell did so at a permanent cost to their total spell pool! In theory one could remove the curse by killing the original caster, but that’d be even harder than creating an anti-spell.”

“I have no idea what that means."

“Of course not" Melson sighed, reaching a hand down to pick me up none too gently. “To cure this creature myself, I’d need to cast a spell that constantly reverts him to his natural form just as often as the current curse traps this thing in the body of a mouse. Not only would that be at a permanent cost to my total spell casting abilities, but it’d take more magic than I actually have! If you ever need to repeat that to your superiors, just say it’s long, complicated, and expensive. I’ll work on it.”

“Ok then.” Ronald balked. Glaring slightly at how I was held. “But what was he before? Do you know what the original form was?”

“Of course I do, human! Wouldn’t waste this sort of power on a toad now would you?”

“Wha, human!? Then why are we keeping him in a cage!” Ronald burst.

“He’s not human now, is he? A cage is probably safer than anything else we can carry him in.”

“There is such a thing called dignity.”

“Bah! The man was probably a barbarian savage, or some street urchin who begged the wrong person for food. Don’t worry about it boy, worrying is not going to make things any easier.” Melson stated condescendingly … at the same time carrying me over to the cage I’d come in on. I had barely even gotten to examine the room, and already I was placed back into darkness!

“I still don-"

“You just go on home, I’ll handle things from here on out. These are complex magics, and surely you could not hope to comprehend them well enough to help. Even in the slightest.”

“My shift isn’t over, I still have to …”

“Then go report this mouse’s whereabouts, I’ll let the captain know if anything turns up from my research here. So far as it concerns you, this little mouse is, well, no longer a concern.”

“After how I’ve just seen you handling this ‘mouse’ I’ll think not. I can watch over the little fella better than you can, you have rows upon rows of rodent habitat and hundreds of different subjects to care for. I only have one pet, and as such can focus on him.”

“What does that have to do with anything? You don’t know how to cast magic and you don’t have the mental capacity to do anything along the lines of scientific inquiry. I doubt you can even read.”

“Say that one more time and I’ll crush your fingers.”

I could hear Melson snorting. “Hoho! Oh really? I doubt you can eve- … gack!” the man didn’t get to finish his statement before Ronald was on him. I scrambled to look through the tiny air holes and see how the fight was going, but the angle was off. I never got the pleasure of seeing Melson in a chokehold, or slammed against the wall, or whatever it was Ronald was doing to subdue the man. All I could hear was the shuffling as they both struggled for control.

“I’ve spent years scouring every tome I could find, greedily thirsting after every scrap of knowledge any passing merchant might bring in. I don’t care how well your little lab full of cages works for holding war criminals, but if that’s how you handle an injured mouse then your either too dumb to care for him properly or your too sadistic. Frankly I don’t care which, he’s not staying with you.”

I heard someone gasping for breath, then I felt my cage jerk suddenly as someone picked it up.

“I c-could *cough* I could …” Melson was too out of breath to finish a sentence.

“If you still want to get paid for this then what you can do is work out a possible solution. Otherwise I’ll just go find a better magician to change him back to normal.” after a pause, Ronald added. “Unless you want to go again? Your magic really should give you an edge once you can breath again.”

Melson seemed to consider this, or at least I interpreted the unseeing silence as deep consideration. I had entirely too much time to think about the smells of death, and rat pee, and decaying bodies that lingered at the edge of my awareness … it made me wonder just what Ronald knew about Melson that I didn’t. The fat mage was supposed to cage war criminals? When waging war against puny rats I guess the magi/scientist who experiments on them would be the ideal choice to hold them.

So if Ronald wanted to make sure I wasn’t kept here, it meant he wanted to make absolutely certain there was a distinction between me and the rodents they're fighting.

“Fine. Come back in a week or so, I’ll send a messenger out for information and have at least a plausible answer by that time.”

“Thank you, oh wise bottle-lord.” Ronald managed without a trace of sarcasm. “And now how much for that bottle of sleep aid?”

The cage shook as Ronald turned and pointed at something, but I couldn’t see much.

“Hmm? Oh! You mean you’re here as a customer too … thirty silver pieces, but remember to only take a drop. Down the whole bottle in a night and you’d be asleep so long you’d starve to death before you awake.”

“I’ll take it.” some more shifting, the sound of coins jingling in a bag, then finally footsteps through a doorway. “See you in a week.”

The door closed. The scent of death and horror vanished, to be replaced by pie and pasta and cake … such a drastic difference in the two. And then I heard the quiet footsteps of a thousand different people as Ronald made his way through the streets.

“Okay, I’m taking you to my home for a while. Not sure what all we can do here, but I believe there is such a thing as human decency. I’ve got a pet rat you mig- … oh wait, your not a real rodent. Well I’ve got a pet rat and I’ve studied mice, so I know what will make you feel comfortable until someone can change you back. But I’ll only have time to drop you off before I’ve got to go, my shift isn’t over yet.”

I nodded … before realizing no one could see inside the cage. So I shouted instead. “THANK YOU!” which was almost as loud as my growling stomach. I still hadn’t eaten yet, and all that food smell around me made my mouth water.

The cage shifted and shook, to which Ronald responded by saying “Sorry ma’am, won’t happen again.” to whoever it was he’d bumped in to.

Was I really going to stay like this for a week? Okay, at the moment it didn’t sound so bad. So long as I got something to eat and drink soon enough I probably wouldn’t even suffer through it. Relaxing in a cage next to another rat sounded far more pleasant than traveling through monster infested jungles on my own, or sliding down the gullet of some starved predator. But then what happens if I never turn back to normal? What if this spell was completely irreversible through conventional means?

Well, if that were the case I wouldn’t have bothered with a normal, boring life inside a cage. I’d hunt down that black garbed spell caster and kill him, see if that breaks his spell. True I might just end up with an even more horrible curse, like turned into a worm … or a sock … or a toilet. But chances were I’d die a more interesting death long before that could ever happen.

It wasn’t hard to make the decision that an interesting death was more fun than a boring life. No way was I going to die of old age munching on cheese.

I heard a door open, then the sounds of someone stepping on dry wood.

“Morning Ronald. Took your little pet for a walk I see?”

“Nope, cought him in the streets a little earlier. This is the mouse that beat up Sir Nickolas.” my cage shifted as he held it up higher.

“Oh wow.” the feminine voice from somewhere to my left sounded surprised.

“Talk to you about it later, for now I’ve got to drop him off then get back to work.”

“Oh, alright then.” the lady muttered as Ronald walked off. Just before she called out …

1111111111111111121.content:
“Say hello to Joyline for me”

“Eh? Oh sure, sure.” Ronald responded before walking making his way through dimly lit hallways. I felt a tingling in my spine as the cage went from chest height to the floor in an instant and gravity seemed to vanish, before it came back in stride as I actually landed. “Ack! Sorry little gu- … erm, Xander.”

I grumbled a half inteligable response, knowing full well he wasn’t going to hear anything I said, while his hand rummaged through his pockets. Keys appeared amidst the clatter of metal on metal, I heard a click as he jammed it into the door, and then a loud creak as the door opened. My cage was hefted up, I was carried into the room and placed on … something. I couldn’t really tell what was in here, the place was so dark.

“Hello Joyline, Cicily says hello.” Ronald called into the darkness, to which there was no response.

“Um … who are you talking to?” I started to ask, before the top of my cage of unlocked with a small ‘click’ and the metal portion slid up.

“Play nice with each other, I’ll be back in three hours if I’m not booked for overtime.” he hurried out the door, and then the entire room got darker as he close it. I heard nothing but his distant footprints as he walked off and left me alone … in a room … with someone called Joyline?

“Um … hello?” I called out, still sitting in the cage but now able to look up at a roof. “Is anyone … Gah!” I squeaked and fell over backwards as a massive, white, whiskery face peaked over the edge of my metal cage.

“Hello there, I’m Joyline. Who are you? Are you another rat? No your too small. Need help getting out of the cage? I like cages so long as Alpha Rat leaves the door open, otherwise I don’t like cages, not much room to explore.” staring down at me with soft white fur, silvery whiskers, and bulging red eyes was a rat. A docile looking rat with clean fur and the faint scent of soap, but still a rat.

The first thing about her I noted was the fact she was a rat. With a rat smell. Rat smell that smelled suspiciously like rat pee. I wasn’t entirely sure why the fact she was a rat made so many alarm bells go off in my head, but it was hard to focus on anything else. Maybe because rats eat mice? I’d probably focus on a cat the same way if I ever saw one.

The second thing I noticed was how feminine she was, eerily attractive in appearance, smell, and sound … but then their’s that whole ‘she’s a rat’ concept which ruins it. Her fur was white, her tail was long and thick, she had these pinkish spots of fur along her back and left cheek. The third thing I noticed as she leapt over the walls and into my cage with a soft Wump was just how BIG she was!

This rat was huge! A little under three times my size! Looking at the difference between me and her was like noting the difference between a human and an ogre! She was more muscular too, I could actually see the muscles bulging in her haunches and on her arms. When she opened her mouth to talk I saw razor sharp teeth half the size of my head, and a long pink gullet that I’d probably be sliding into one piece at a time if I pissed her off.

“Hello? Do you talk? I thought you’d be able to talk, most of the mice I’ve seen could. Until the rat army chased them all away and now I don’t have anyone to talk to. I mean Alpha Rat is nice and all, when he’s around, but he can’t squeak normally and he’s a little loud even when he tries. If you can’t talk that’s okay, I’ll just talk enough for the both of us, do you know what month old peanuts smell like? Apparently they smell just like week old peanuts, that was the biggest disappointment of my life. You see, it has to do with all the salt humans put in their food, makes it last longer than you’d think.”

The fourth thing I noticed was just how much she talked. “Um, th-that’s nice.”

“Yeah, yeah it is. Oh, hey! So you can talk? That’s great!” she charged towards me, too fast to dodge in this poor lighting, and wrapped both arms around my shoulders. It was the strangest hug I’d ever felt. “My name is Joyline, what’s yours?”

“Um, X-Xander. A pleasure to make your acquaintance Joyline. Can you let go of me now?” I started to push my hands against her, hands half the size of her own, and balked at just how squishy and fluffy the flesh that surrounded me was. Her belly had such loose skin and so much fat she could have probably held me down by just laying there. Probably … it was very soft fur, I might have been able to slide out.

But Joyline just hugged tighter, actually curling her thick tail around the both of us. “It’s Joyline, pronounced ‘joy-leen’ you know, because I’m lean and I bring joy? It’s not Joy-line, there is no ‘line’ involved in the pronunciation of my name, my name is completely without lines unless you want to spell it.”

“Gack! Okay, okay, JoyLeeeen, there. I’ll do whatever you say, just don’t eat me before Ronald gets back!” I pleaded. I probably should have fought, maybe I could have. I’ve taken on ogres and trolls in single, hand to hand combat. I knew how to take down a larger and stronger opponent. Perhaps the same tricks would enable a mouse to overpower a rat? But if I hurt Joyline then I’m pretty darn certain Ronald would have nothing to do with me, so if my pride were to suffer for the sake of survival then by golly my pride was going to suffer.

“Eat you? Well okay, I’ll wait. I wasn’t planning on eating you to begin with, I’ve got plenty of food around and I’m really full, and someone to talk to is more valuable at the moment than someone to fill my belly. But if you have some sort of sick fascination with it I can eat you after Alpha Rat gets home. But I really wouldn’t want to, and I think you should ask Alpha Rat to eat you instead. He’s got a bigger mouth.”

I blinked. “Er, no I don’t want to be eaten period, just a little frightened by the massive … squish hug … going on here. Can you please let me go?”

“Oh, oh sure!” Joyline loosened her grip, dropped me onto two feet, then held out a single paw. I grabbed it, letting her massive hand close around mine like I were a child, and we shook hands. “Nice to meet you too Xander, but are you going to stay in this cage all day? I mean really, it’s a nice place to sleep but it can’t be all that fun.”

“Sure, I’ll leave … just … just give me a minute to take in what’s happening here.”

“Okay, a full minute? Lets see, one … two … three … four …”

I slapped a paw to my face. “That doesn’t mean for you to actually count, I ju- …” but she interrupted me she shoving her massive head over my shoulders and twitching her whiskers across my tail.

“Hey! Your injured, aren’t you? Why do you have that bandage over it? Did you live with a different Alpha Rat before Ronald?”

I blinked, realizing just who ‘alpha rat’ was in this girl’s mind. “No, I put that on myself.”

“Oh neat! That’s just amazing! Can you show me how? I’ll treat the wounds in exchange if you want, I’ve got some nice herbs in a hidy place that’ll clear up any pain you might be feeling. Will have to wait for Alpha Rat to get back if you want to disinfect it though, Ronald hides it from me because he doesn’t like seeing me drunk.”

I blinked. Squeezed out from under the girl’s chin, then snorted at the mental image of a drunk rat stumbling around. “N-no, I should imagine not.”

“No? Awww, but why?!” Joyline pouted, visibly upset.

“I meant the part about Ronald keeping alcohol away from you, not … I’ll show you how to make a bandage and tie knots, no problem! Don’t worry about that.”

“Yay! Oh! But how do we make it? I don’t mean physically, well I do want to know how to physically do it, but what I mean is we only have one rag at the moment and it’s holding your tail together.”

“My tail is not injured that badly” I retorted, only to blink in surprize as the rat stuck her tongue out at me.

“Doesn’t mean we need to tail your bandage silly. Back to my earlier question, are you coming out or not?” and with that she scurried over to one side of the cage, coiled her hind legs while loosening the pressure on her front legs … then LEAPT!

She practically flew the ten inches to the top of the cage and landed daintily on the wall. Apparently her balance was just as good, or better, than my own in this new body.

“Um, s-sure.” I started towards the wall myself, coiled my legs, and LEAPT!

11111111111111111211.content:
I leapt through the air at impressive speed, my front paws outstretched, my hind paws and tail trailing behind me … wait, paws? No! Think of them as hands, their hands you idiot! Moments before …

SMACK

I smashed nose first into the metal wall, then slumped back down. As I was groggily getting back to my feet all I could hear was this laughter in my ears. A real laughter apparently.

“Hahahaha! Oh wow, that was the funniest thing I’ve ever seen! You’re all like, ‘Wooosh!’ and then wall’s all ‘you shall not pass’ and then your all like, ‘Smack!’ and ‘ahh! I’m falling!’ Hahaha! It j- it just doesn’t get much funnier than that.” Joyline was laughing it up from her perch on the cage wall, cleverly out of my reach. I made a silent wish that she laugh so hard she falls off, but considering a rodent’s balance while on four legs, that was an unlikely scenario.

“I’m glad one of us enjoyed that ma’am.” I grumbled while rubbing my cheek. My face really, really hurt after ramming it into the wall like that. Looking up, I wondered how I could have missed the jump. What was it too high? I’d jumped higher than that trying to get onto a horse. Er, but then again, while chasing after the horse I had the advantage of a running start, whereas here I had to jump strait up.

“You are? Really? I would have thought you’d be annoyed by my laughing, that’s why I didn’t jump down to help you.” snickering some more. “But if you enjoy my enjoyment then I’ll just keep on enjoying.” a big smile was plastered to her face.

I blinked … then slapped a paw to my face. Then decided to ask “Well can you help me up now? I’d rather not do that again.”

Joyline just giggled. “Oh but I’d rather you did, your so much fun when your smacking into things.” she swiveled around on her hind legs, balanced lengthwise against the cage wall, then hung her long tail down as far as it could reach. “Here you are, just hop up and grab it.”

I scurried over to the wall, did a short little hop, then gripped onto the rat’s tail with my tiny little paws. It was like holding onto a wriggly two-by-four, the tail was thicker than my hand! But I curled my legs around, griping with my hips as well as my arms, then started to climb up. It was an easy climb, up until I got to her rump … I paused, unsure of how to proceed.

“Well go on, climb the rest of the way up. Unless you want me to just jump over and we all go flying onto the bed.” she giggled once more, a laugh that I felt would quickly grow tiring.

“N-no-no, I’ll just …” but she cut me off.

“No? Your not going to climb? Well alright then, over the wall we go, Weeeeeee!”

“Wait, what? Gah!” I only had time to hold on tighter before the rat was falling to her side and I was trailing behind her. Her tail and mine intertwining like little streamers. We landed on softness with a ‘thwump’ before bouncing a moment, and then something soft and silky landed on top of me.

I blinked, then I sniffed. Then I decided I shouldn’t have sniffed, it smelled like rat pee …

“Now that’s an interesting place for your head to and up.” Joyline stated while lifting her belly off of mine and wriggling the tail my grip was held on. As the white softness moved, I saw two pink holes surrounded by white fur and bulging hips, the private areas of a female rat currently sitting on my head.

“This was not by design I assure you.”

“Maybe not your design, but I’ve got no problems with this.” Joyline taunted before sitting back down.

“Huh-, hey wait!” I scrambled to let go of the tail and move out of the way, but the rat was just as fast as I was and didn’t have as far to go. Her full weight pressed down against me, her belly bulged around either side as her soft gut squished and molded to conform to my shape. Interestingly enough, so was my own belly. Neither of us looked especially fat, but it was clear from how the skin moved that rodents typically had more meat proportional to their bodies than humans did. Heck, by comparison to this rat, the average human was a stick figure and an overweight human was just too short for their belly.

I pushed up with my hands, but the belly just conformed around them rather than move out of the way. I wriggled back and forwarth, kicking without any purchase and waving my tail around. Then I squeaked as something strong gripped the tip of it.

“OooOooo … this tail is so soft.” Joyline murmured as her fingers pulled my tail up towards her face and she rubbed her cheeks against it.

“Plah! Can you please get off of me!” I shouted out from underneath an overly ‘playful’ rodent. My head shifted from left to right, plowing through her and pushing her legs to the side much the same way a shovel goes through dirt, until … I gasped for breath, inhaling deeply the moment my head was out from under her. Okay, it was still between her legs, and she was still on top of me, but now I could breath fresh air.

“Of course I will, after a quick nap.” she stated in a smug town while making an exaggerated yawn.

“Joyline!”

“Ok, fine, I’ll get up …” she rolled off to one side and I bounded onto all four legs, but her paw maintained it’s solid grip on my tail. “Happy now? Ooh! Just how did you get that cut? Were you attacked by a cat?” she asked while pulling me in closer and poking my bandage with her free paw.

“No, I got that while learning how dangerous a sidewalk can be. Joyline, why are you so grabby?” I demanded. Not quite angry, but her antics were exhausting.

“You’re the first rodent I’ve seen in months, and even better, you’re the first person I can talk to in so long … well, Alpha Rat and a few others talk to me, but no one understands what I’m saying or answers my questions, so it gets boring.”

I blinked, starting to get the picture. “Oh.”

“Worse still is that most of the time I’ve got absolutely no one, so I find entertaining things to do.” she blinked, then dropped my tail before bounding off to the edge of the bed with massive leaps, her run reminding me of a bunny rabbit.

“Uh …”

“Wait here a minute, I just remembered something fun we can try!” she called back before dropping to the floor with a half silent thump.

“Try what?” I called back, scurrying over to the edge of the bed so I could see her. Meanwhile, I also saw the room for the first time, and was overwhelmed by the sheer number of books. There were books everywhere! On the shelves, on the table, a few thick ones were at the head of Ronald’s bed. Joyline had to climb over a few of them in her path to … wherever.

The bed was in the very center of the room, with a single table and chair to the left overlooking a window, and shelving that did an adequate job of holding on to each of the tomes. To the left was the doorway we’d entered, a simple, inornate, wooden door. At the foot of the bed, back a few feet, was a separate desk with a large glass cage on it. Looking inside I could see ramps, blocks of wood with holes in them, strips of torn bedding, lots of things a pet rat would love. Looking down the edge of the bed, I saw a single plate of food left out, right next to a full thing of water, but it seemed as if the food dish was there to torture me and nothing more. It was empty …

My stomach grumbled.

“Ah! Here we are.” Joyline called back up merrily, and I looked down to see her idea of a good way to pass the time was …
11111111111111111211.title: I fail, and fall back down.

11111111111111111212.content:
SMACK!

My head smashed into the side of the cage, halfway up the actual length of the wall, and I was too disoriented to see anything. I fell back down and landed on my side with a ‘thwump’ while the cage swung over to the side.

“Eep!” Joyline squeaked, flailing her tail for balance as the cage began to tip over. Not wanting to be crushed under it, the rat leapt off her perch and went sailing onto the bed. But the force of her jump and the sudden loss of her weight on that side made the entire thing rock back in the opposite direction. I squeaked out in terror, scrambling back to four legs as the sudden feeling of weightlessness told me the cage was falling off the side of the bed.

“Ack!” I screamed in pain as I slammed my wrist into one of the tumbling walls, only to scream even louder as the whole world exploded in gut wrenching sounds that vibrated through every fiber of my being. The metal cage had slammed into the wooden floor, and from inside the hallow of it that sound was something dreadful.

“Xander!” Joyline called out in alarm. I heard the ‘thump’ as she jumped off the bed after me, but all I could see were spinning … blobby … spinny things. Lots and lots of spinning. “Xander, are you … are you ok?”

I heard her ask the question as a white, adorable little rat face poked into the cage and twitched it’s whiskers over my cheeks. “Y-yeah, I’m …” I started to lie, before I tried to get up. Putting pressure on my wrist I realized something very quickly. “No, no I’m not fine. I think I sprained my wrist in the crash.”

“Eek! Well don’t worry, I’ll go get sheet of cloth. We move you onto it, then I can drag you through the room to my hidy hole. I’ll be back in a moment, you stay here if you can’t walk.” she pressed her nose against my nose, then vanished in a flurry of scurrying noises.

I flexed my still injured tail, felt along the crease of my freshly injured hand, then twitched my whiskers to sniff the air better. The whole place smelled like Joyline, and rat pee, and Ronald, and … glue? It smelled like glue and paper and ink, almost like a library. Just not as much dust. To get a better look at those smells, I crawled up to two legs and started to walk out of the cage. Blinking, I saw a simple, unadorned room with a large bed in the center, a wooden door, and two desks.

One was way behind me on the other side of the bed, right next to a window … this one was covered in books and paper and had this large quill pen. I could almost see a chair from across the room. The other desk was immediately to my right, very, very high up, and had a giant glass rat cage on it. Filled with all the toys and bedding and soft things a rat would supposedly want. Every other wall was hidden by a shelf, and each of those shelves had books or assorted trinkets on them, but none were completely full.

I heard some loud thumping sound that repeated itself, over and over in a clear pattern. Curious, I looked towards the direction of the sound to see a large, plain, wooden door … a large wooden door with shadows moving under the crack in it. I only had enough time to squeak and dive for the cage when the door opened and someone stepped inside.

“Is everything alright in, oh! That must have fallen off.” a female voice boomed across the room, sounding just as massive and earsplitting as every other human I’d encountered. I stood on two legs and propped my back against the wall of the toppled over cage, trying to stay as still and difficult to see as possible. Then I realized my location wasn’t the best of choices.

Her feet seemed to slam into the floor with every step, crunching into wood as she stomped her way across the room. Okay, maybe she was stepping daintily and not actually stomping, but it was just too loud to think of that sound as anything else. Anyone who’s never been a mouse has no idea just how loud those simple movements are.

I trembled as she stepped right next to the cage, I could see her feet, pasty white skin slipped into simple wooden sandals with rope straps holding them on. Cheap and easy to make, but not necessarily comfortable. Worse still, they were perfect for crushing something underfoot, which is exactly where my worries were taking my train of thought. All of a sudden the entire cage shook, and the view of this girl’s feet became a view of her legs, then her simple brown skirt, then … the roof.

I fell backwards as she flipped the cage around, squeaking in pain as the far wall became the floor and I fell a good six feet … okay, maybe it was inches in reality, but the fall was equivalent And it HURT!

“Ah!” I heard her thundering voice scream out and felt a sudden weightlessness as she dropped the cage. But I didn’t even have enough time to be afraid of falling a second time before the whole thing shuddered and her hands closed around it. “Gotcha. Sorry, didn’t know anyone was in there.”

I feel to my side as the wall once again became the floor and the roof of the metal box oriented towards the girl’s face. “H-hello ma’am.”

She blinked, staring at me wide eyed, before setting the cage back on the bed and laying on it’s side so I could crawl out. “Wow, so you really can talk. Oh! Where’s Joyline?”

I groaned, shifting on to two legs so my injured paw wouldn’t matter, then carefully walked out. It was so much harder on two legs. Not really impossible, and my balance wasn’t much worse off from when I was human, but compared to the superb balance of a mouse on four legs I was as wobbly as a one legged table.

“Ack! You not supposed to be here human, why are you in here?” I heard Joyline shouting up at the girl, though as the human bent down I could see neither of them. “Xander? Where did you go! I told you to stay put!”

“Ah, there you are. You want to come up little rat?” the woman called out.

I decided, hey with all this yelling going on, why not join in? “I’m up on the bed Joyline! This … whoever this is put me up here.” I screamed at the top of my lungs.

In just that moment the woman stood back up and stared at me with Joyline cupped carefully on her palm. She had deep blue eyes, muddy blond hair that would have been luxurious if she could use the same expensive soaps and shampoos the royals enjoy, but instead looked plain and ordinary. Her skin was white, as I’d seen earlier, but from this much better angle I could tell how soft and smooth it looked. There weren’t half as many noticeable pours or beads of sweat oozing out as there had been on Melson or Ronald.

She was staring at me with the same intensity I was staring at her. Almost as if she couldn’t believe what just happened.

“Y-you can talk.” she stated lamely.

“Well of course he can talk! He’s a mouse, whoever said mice can’t talk?” Joyline shouted out, but her words went ignored.

I stood there a moment, my injured wrist held against my chest, before stepping back into a solid stance and swinging my nose towards the bed in a low, formal bow. My tail hung out for ballence while my free hand swung behind me. “Yes I can M’lady, I am Xander. Might I ask who you are?” then I stood back up and looked at her. My uninjured hand swung around to nurse my other one.

“C-ci … Cicily.” she looked to Joyline, then carefully set the rat on the bed next to me.

“Humph. See what I mean? No one ever understands what I say. How come she responds to you?”

“A pleasure to meet you Cicily” I stated before turning to Joyline. “Something about the spell perhaps, I can hear you just fine. Sort of which humans could talk as quietly as you.”

At that Joyline giggled. “Makes yer ears hurt doesn’t it? Don’t worry, you’ll get used to that.”

“Spell? But I th- … oh! You were talking to Joyline?” the woman’s face brightened as she pointed to the white rat.

I held my good ear up to my head to block some of the sound before responding. “Yes ma’am, I can talk to you both apparently. It’s going to become a confusing conversation if …” but I was interrupted by a sharp pain and loud grumbling in my stomach. I bent over and cupped my hand across my belly instead of my head, but struggled to keep from falling on my face. “Er, m-my apologies. I have not eaten in quite some time.”

Both Joyline and Cicily looked concerned. “Oh dear … well I’d … I love to talk to you both, if only to hear what you think of me Joyline.” she stated while reaching a hand out to scritch the rat’s ears. “But I’ve got to get back to the counter and watch for customers. I only came up here because I heard the noise, I wanted to check if everything was still in one piece.”

“I see. Thank you … for your concern ma’am” I struggled back to two feet, trying to hold both my aching hand and my aching stomach at the same time.

“Oh I’ll get you some food Xander, no problem! I’ve got lots and lots of food stashed up. I think there’s a strawberry around here somewhere from a few weeks ago.”

Then Cicily stated. “If you’d like I can take you into the other room and get you something to eat.”

Knowing that Cicily didn’t hear Joyline’s suggestion, I also knew full well I wasn’t planning on eating month old moldy strawberries … or month old peanuts. Though I’m certain she had more stashed around. “I’d like that.” then I looked over to the rat, before glancing back up at Cicily and saying: …

1111111111111111122.content:
“Don’t forget the rent is due, Ronald. You know I can’t afford to give you any leeway when it comes to payment, I have my own bills to make.” the girl stated. Or at least I hoped it was a girl, for her voice was ridiculously feminine.

“Gah!” Ronald yelped in a comical fashion, making the floor of my cage jump around in response to his startled gesture. Moments later I felt the cage slam noisily onto a wooden desk and Ronald call out “Here, can you hold him for a moment? I’ll be right back”

“Um, s-sure?” the girl asked tentatively, moments before a door opened and slammed shut.

I stood there, in almost complete darkness, just waiting for whatever was going to happen next. Then I kept waiting. And I waited some more. How long was Ronald going to be exactly? I scurried over to the side of the cage and relaxed my head against the wall. A short squeak escaped my lips as I closed my eyes and tried not to think about food. Funny thing about not thinking about something? It’s impossible to not think about the thing your trying not to think about because you have to think about it to make the decision to not think about it. Long story short? I thought about food.

“Grumble!” and my stomach growled loudly in response to that.

“Eep! Hey, no growling mister. Or I’ll sit on that cage.” the girl threatened.

I balked at that, cupped my hands around my mouth and then placed it as close to the airholes as I could manage before shouting out my response. “I was not growling ma’am! That was my stomach complaining, for I have not eaten in over a day!” immediately after I coughed. It was hard trying to yell so loudly so often, and the thundering voices of most every human I’d met were giving me a headache. Lovely as this girl’s voice was, she was no exception.

“Er, oh? S-so your just hungry then?”

I leapt back as a massive blue eye covered the airhole and peered into the cage at me. Gulping in mild fear, I stood up to two legs and loudly proclaimed “That is correct miss, I shall try to quiet my stomach if the noise displeases you.” then I slumped back to four legs and cupped one arm across my belly. I wasn’t lying, rule number one about surviving near giants is to not make said giants angry with you.

The eyeball blinked, then giggled. Her head moving around enough for me to see the white skin and muddy blond hair on the rest of her face. “That sounds … well that sounds silly to me, if your hungry you should ask for something to eat.” her head moved away from the airholes and I could hear her place her hands on the roof of my cage.

“I have no money to pay for food.” I called out.

“What? I can’t hear you.”

Sighing, I stood up and shouted out as loudly as my tiny lungs could manage. “I HAVE NO MONEY TO PAY FOR IT!”

She apparently heard me this time. “Your worried about money? Why would a mouse worry about paying for the food it takes.” I looked up to see the tiniest crack in my roof. She was trying to peer inside without giving me a means of escape.

“I am no true mouse, but a royal guard, a soldier, cursed to take this form because I defended my king. I may look like a mouse at the moment, but I am no cowardly thief.” I made sure to yell the entire sentence loudly, it was making my throat sore but then so would repeating myself over and over again.

The cage roof slammed shut and that tiny crack of light vanished in an instant. “Really?”

I nodded … sighed when I realized she couldn’t see it, then shouted out “YES!”

“Wow, that’s probably the worst fate imaginable around here. This city is loaded with deathtraps for all little rodents sense the rat army started making raids. And you’re a mouse! So even the rats around here would attack and eat you, you’ll be in danger from either side in this war.”

I blinked at that one, not quite sure how to respond. All of a sudden I felt very glad I chose to let myself be captured and interrogated, rather than run off on my own and fall prey to something more insidious. After a few moments of silence, the girl said something that made me smile brighter than I have all week.

“Well, my name’s Cicily. I’ve got a few cookies here, would you like to share one?”

Unable to believe my ears, I leapt up to two feet and called out as loudly as I could in a voice that exuded pure happiness. “Yes! Yes I would ma’am, that would be wonderful!” all the while trying to ignore a little voice in the back of my head saying ‘don’t get too excited Xander, she could just be teasing you with the promise of food without actually planning to give you any.’

“Okay, but you’ve got to promise to stay absolutely still … I can’t open the cage for you, alright? If you could beat of Nickolas then I don‘t want to know what you‘d do to my tavern.”

I nodded my head. “Such terms are acceptable ma’am.”

Then I heard giggling. “You don’t have to call me ma’am all the time, Cicily will do just fine.” just before the cage opened. A pearly white hand surrounded by a halo or lantern light slowly shifted into my dark little metal box, a glorious, delicious smelling cookie gripped tightly between her fingers. The smell was so wonderful, my belly gurgled, demanding I feed it as soon as possible. That girl’s hand might as well have been angels sent by god for all I knew. The moment she set the cookie down next to my head, I gripped part of it in my paws, tore off a piece, then sat on two legs while munching happily.

She lifted the rest of the cookie out of my cage and closed the lid back over it … she seemed quick about it, as if expecting me to leap out and tear her face off the moment I had an opening. I thought that was silly. Even if I wanted to (which I most certainly did not!) she was much too big to actually damage. At this size, I doubted even my now sharp teeth could have broken her skin.

“Are you alright in there? Was that enough?” she asked, sounding like some mix between concerned and curious.

I mumbled out something unintelligible with my cheeks bulging and my teeth very active, swallowed hard, then tried again. Making sure to shout so she could hear me this time “Yes! Oh yes, thank you milady!! I mean, miss Cicily.”

She snorted, then giggled. “Just Cicily is fine, you don’t need to call me miss.”

I took a few small nibbles then called out “Either way I thank you, I had worried I would never find a meal.” my own little piece was getting smaller and smaller by the moment. Soon it would be gone. “Um, s-speaking of which … can I have some more?” I’d shout before gulping down the last little crumb. Even if she denied me, my belly was sated for the moment. The cookies were bland and simple, but I had simple tastes and everything tastes good if your hungry enough.

“Hmm … how about we get you out of there. If … if only for a moment.” then before I could answer she opened up the cage and both of her hands shot in after me. I squeaked as one finger closed around my head, two more closed around my waist, and then her pinky stabbed into my injured tail.

“Ack!” I flinched, arching my head back. To which she responded by dropping me. That wasn’t pleasant either.

“Eek! I’m sorry, I’m sorry, what happened?!” at least she was genuinely concerned. That had to count for something.

“It’s, m-my tail.” I stated weakly.

“What?” apparently I wasn’t loud enough to hear, so I tried again.

“It’s my tail!”

“Oh!” she gasped, cupping her hands under me this time. She used one wall of fingers to push me over to her other wall of fingers. I was slowly getting up to all four feet as she lifted me out gently. “I’m sorry little guy, didn’t mean to hurt you. Did you get that cut during the fight with Nick?”

I shook my head. “No, someone stepped on it. I shall endeavor to watch where I’m going in the near future.”

“Oh you poor thing … here, have the rest of your cookie.” she lifted it towards me face and watched me hungrily attack the delicious little thing. I sat up on two legs to hold the piece of a cookie and squeaked happily as I gulped it down. Oh yes, this more than made up for accidentally squeezing my tail, this woman was once again an angel in my eyes.

“Oh! Your soooooo cute!” she squealed, watching me eat for the first time. As I licked the crumbs off my paws … er, no hands! They were hands! The next words out of her mouth startled me.

11111111111111112.content:
“Oh right away then” the man grunted, sounding even more annoyed at the situation. His hand grasped for me a second time … or rather slapped. His palm pressing me against the side and floor the cage so I could not run, his thick, pudgy fingers closed around my head and arms. My bandaged tail and injured legs left to dangle bellow me, I was lifted up into the colorful, mold and death smelling room.

There were books and bottles and strewn paper all over the place. A thick wooden table with a vat of ink, a pen, and an empty sheet of paper were the most space he had available. Everywhere else was overflowing with some trinket or oddly shaped bottle, to the point if a thief were to pick through and steal half of it you’d still never get to see the shelving underneath. Lots of great looking places to hide …

I felt that should have been a warning bell.

He dropped me unceremoniously onto an empty part of his desk, and I had roughly three seconds to regain my balance and look up at the fat man before both hands cupped over and around me. I squeaked lightly, glancing from one finger to the next as he spread them … I covered my eyes when they emit a soft glow.

“Ohohoh! This thing is a shapeshifer! Or more accurately, has been polymorphed against it’s will.”

“Huh, so it used to be something else. That explains why it fights better than a mouse.” I heard Ronald’s muffled voice through fat fingers. “Can you change it back?”

“Lets find out.” Melson sounded determined, just before the glow intensified. There was this odd tingling sensation that seemed to flow through my skin, my fur, my very bones … I could see my fur disappearing, my tail shrunk and swiveled, my face seemed to crush in on itself as my jaws shortened. Just before my world exploded into pain.

I felt pain as my face seemed torn between growing and shinking, though to my horror the elongation back into a mouse like jaw structure was winning out. I felt pain as my tail grew and shifted, the bandage growing snug once more as the flesh it covered filled back out. I felt unrelenting, horrible, horrible agony as every single piece of fur coming out of my skin felt like a dagger stabbing through me. It felt exactly like that first time I was transformed.

I fell to my side as the glow faded. I was breathing hard, my vision was blurry, and worst of all I was still a mouse.

‘By the gods I hate magic’ I muttered.

“Odd …” Melson stated while I focused solely on recovery.

“So, what does that mean … you can’t cure it? We have to go find some other magic user?”

“Hohohohoho!” Melson burst into a fit of giggles, the fat on his belly and arms jiggling at random. “Not just ‘different’ my boy, you’d need an entirely new caliber of magician here. You probably won’t understand any of this technical stuff but that mouse is con- …” but Melson was interrupted.

“If I won’t get it then don’t say it, what your saying here is that we need a better magician than you. Right?”

Groaning and gasping for breath, I almost smiled as I looked up to see an expression of annoyance on Melson’s face. He wasn’t getting much respect here.

“In a way, yes. Yes … most definitely. You’d probably need one of the greatest magicians of all time to undue this sort of spell. Your talking people who can vaporize a city by waving their arms around and thinking really hard. People who’ve mastered teleportation, or mass/energy manipulation. More power than all the magicians you’ve ever heard of on this side of the planet combined! More power than …” once more he was interrupted.

“I get it! We need someone with a lot of power.” at which point Ronald extended his hands, cupped one over my back and one under my chest, before carefully lifting up. Once all four feet were under his palm he positioned me so that I’d be more comfortable with his fingers surrounding me while also allowing my head to stick out.

I looked across at Melson’s workbench, the papers and tomes he had littered all over the place, the various bottles of all different colors and sizes he had lined against the shelves. But that scent of rat pee, death and decay from somewhere in the corner of my senses distracted from all of the more interesting sights … and I tucked my head back between the two human palms. Ronald’s sweat was far more pleasant than that lingering scent in Melson’s house.

“So now, let me see here …” Melson started sliding a finger against one book after another, searching for one in particular. “I’m supposed to break the enchantment, correct? Given time I could probably craft the specific counter spell I’d need, but I’d also need time to build up physical, raw, power. Time or money, whichever we have more of.”

“I see … whether I’ll understand it or not, could you explain what you know in a little more detail?”

Melson frowned and moved past the books, now inspecting one random jewel after another. “Whoever cast that transformation spell didn’t just cast a single, simple spell, they set it up so that a living spell within his body is constantly recasting the transformation every second of every day. My power isn’t just blocked or else he wouldn’t have changed at all, the spell recast itself before I could turn him back to human. Even if we did change him all the way, he’d just turn into a mouse again the moment we stop casting at him.”

Ronald blinked. “H-human?” Looking at me curiously before shaking his head. “ok, so we need … what? A way to get the other spell out of him?”

“That would require killing the original spell caster, or somehow persuading him to end it. Neither would be any small feat mind you, assuming you can even find the man there’s every possibility he’d just cast an even worse curse against you. Or kill you outright so that he can get the mana back without any of the headache.”

Ronald gulped. “Do you know of anyone we could go to then? The guy’s … this used to be a human and now he’s living out his life as a mouse.”

I saw Melson glare slightly, but then his face saddened … it seemed slightly out of character to me. “Well I can take care of him no problem, I’ve got the safest little home fo- …”

“No.” Ronald stated both boldly and flatly.

“Wh- …”

“I’ll hold on to him, after seeing how you handle rodents I don’t nearly trust you around one.”

“I’m the scientist designated to cage and study them! I know a hundred times more about rat care than you’ll ever know!” Melson exploded with anger, apparently upset that Ronald wasn’t even about to fall for any fake nice person act he could put on. Not that he even tried for very long … or put that much effort into it.

“I’ve been keeping a pet rat for longer than you’ve had this lab ‘bottle-lord’ and seeing as w- … we …” all of a sudden Ronald looked confused. “Why is that bottle ...”

I turned my weary gaze over towards the section of the wall Ronald pointed to, then looked back to see Melson turn white with fear. That was an odd reaction.

“Oh! That’s a, uh … a project I’ve been working on. I need privacy to finish that one, lots of toxic fumes and such, so if your going to be such a pain about it.” fat, pudgy hands scooped me up off the table and shoved me into Ronald’s chest. It wasn’t gentle, but I think I was too tired to actually flinch at the pain. Ronald’s grip, while fast, was much more gentle.

“Uh …”

“Go, go on now. I’ll handle this from here.” Melson stated frantically while pushing Ronald from behind then scanning through the bottles. His hands shot out to grab a purple and green angular one. “I’m serious, get gone already!”

“Oook …” Ronald stared blankly, before walking out the door with me cupped in his hands. I took this opportunity to see the section of the village I was in, some distance down the street from where I was captured. Blinking, I realized this was the exact same street.

Melson’s house and shop looked little different from the rest of the stone and wood buildings in the town. The only way I could tell it was anything more than a classic, old building was the fact there were colorful bottles in the windowsill and a wooden sign declaring ‘Ratary’ hanging from two metal chains. There was a bakery to my right, and a library just beyond that, but the two buildings nearest my left had no sign to indicate some purpose.

I assumed they were residential.

“Gah! I, erm …”

Looking up at Ronald, I poked his finger while asking “What?” as loud as I could shout.

“I think I forgot your cage. Should probably go back and get it.”
